Welcome

tcl PyEnchant/abi-word

Message

Welcome to The Web Outline of Logic. I hope you find it a resource for reference and learning. If you find any mistakes, omissions, inaccuracies or just want to make a general comment or suggestion please {{visit( "mailto:ronpro@cox.net" ): email me }}.

Thank you and please come back often. The Web Outline of Logic is always evolving.

How To Use

This web page is divided into multiple frames. The pane on the left contains a navigation tree, while the one on the right (the pane containing this text you are now reading) is the content pane.

The navigation tree is an outline of articles in this web site. When you first load this web site, the navigation tree is completely collapsed (meaning you can only see the top-level articles). Clicking on a [+] will expand one level of the tree while clicking on a [-] will collapse the subtree. The article titles in the tree which are underlined can be clicked. This will cause the article to appear in the content frame.

Every article in the outline is contained in the content pane. It's possible to scroll through all articles in this one frame. However, this is not recommended. The outline in the navigation frame has many levels and it's easy to loose the context of any particular article without using the navigation tree. However, on the chance that you do loose your context, it's still possible to locate yourself. At the top of every article is a 'path' which shows your location in the tree. Each branch in this path is separated by a double colon (::).

Acknowledgments

This site is powered by {{visit( "http://www.natara.com" ): Natara Bonsai }} and my own {{visit( "http://www.python.org" ): python }} utility to convert Bonsai files into this web page.{{BR}}

Organization

Description

The criteria for the organization of this outline are first as a reference and second as a tool for learning. The outline begins with a simple definition of Logic as the study and evaluation of arguments. The next topic of the outline is that of arguments. The primary goal of this section is to introduce the argument from the perspective of the definition of logic provided. That is, the focus of the section is to give the reader all that's needed to know how to identify and evaluate an argument. As added material, the last part of the section on argumentation is on argumentation in the real world. Most courses on logic will either skip this part altogether or else just study the subsection on Fallacies. The fourth section of the outline is a detailed study of the proposition (the first component of an argument). The fifth section is a detailed study of inference (the second component of an argument). After that the outline enters into the more advanced topics of meta theory, philosophy of logic, and a study of non-classical logical systems.

Future versions of this outline will include syllibi for different courses of study.

About

<LI>Version: {{data}}</LI>

<LI>Number of Articles: {{document.articleCount}}</LI>

</UL>

Revision Log

2008.04.23

I've been away for a while working on a new implementation of the tool that generates this website. The tool is quite mature now and I can get back to business evolving the outline.

2007.02.07

Many sections of the outline have been flushed out. I'm now moving the outline in a direction in which it is not so deeply nested. Several corrections have been made. Many of the articles have been flushed out with clearer text.

2005.03.19

Until now, the outline has been organized as a system of reference. This was not a place for someone wishing to learn something about logic. I am not in the process of creating some continuity among the articles with the purpose of making the outline more useful to the casual student of logic. However, the outline is first a reference tool. For any cases which create conflict between the 'outline as a reference' and the 'outline as a learning tool', the first of these criteria will always win out.

2005.03.01

Upgrade of The Logic Web to a fully navigable outline. Welcome to "The Web Outline of Logic".

Logic

{{bookmark( "def.logic" )}}

Definition

Logic is the science that studies and evaluates arguments.

Section Overview

The first section, Argument, will give you a good understanding of what this definition entails. It will lead you from identifying and knowing the parts of an argument, to evaluating an argument.

The remaining sections will expand upon complex topics mentioned in the Argument section.

How Is Logic a Science

Description

When most people think of science, they think of the study of nature and the universe; specifically physics, chemistry and biology. However, the sciences are much broader. Teh sciences may be classified into the empirical (a posteriori) and formal (a priori). The Empirical sciences are the natural sciences. Those which can truely be tested with the scientific method. They include the natural and social sciences (exo- and endosciences). Then formal sciences constitute the metasciences. These are those sciences which study the systems used for talking about the other sciences. This is the realm of Mathematics, Statistcs and Logic (among other more minor sciences).

<PRE>

Science

A Posterieror (Empirical)

Exosciences (Natural, Physical) Independant of human experience

Physics

Chemistry

Biology

Endosciences (Social) Within human experience

Sociaology

Economics

A Priori (Formal)

Metasciences

Linguistics

Logic

Mathematics

Statistics

</PRE>

Hierarchy of Logic & Argumentation

Description

This hierarchy shows where Logic & Argumentation come in the scheme of things.

Hierarchy

<UL>

<LI>Argumentation is a form of Dialectic.</LI>

<LI>Dialectic is a form of Rhetoric.</LI>

<LI>Rhetroic is a form of Discourse.</LI>

</UL>

Discourse

Definition

A sequence of connected sentences. Such as the development of a thought or conversation. As opposed to a bunch of sentences that have no relation to oneanother.

Rhetoric

Definition

<UL>

<LI>The development and communiction of knowledge between speekers and listeners.</LI>

<LI>The study of how messages influence people.</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>From this second definition we can see that argumentation is a subset of rhetoric being the study of how people are influenced by reason-giving (That is, argumentation may be defined of as reason-giving).</LI>

<LI>Thinking Rhetorically requires a certain frame of mind.</LI>

</UL>

[[]]:ordered

@@ Thinking in terms of an audience.

@@ Requires acknowledging audience predispositions and reasoning with them in mind.

@@ Requires awareness of choice by speakers and listeners.

@@ Requires recognizing that influence is noncoercive.

Parts

[[Description]]

@@ Ramus divided the first two into argument and concern with the truth which he said was philosophy. And put the last three into presentation which he said was rhetoric

invention

[[Description]]

@@ Discovering and selecting the facts to be used in making your case.

arrangement

[[Description]]

@@ Orgainzing the facts selected by 'invention'.

style

[[Description]]

@@ How you present the argument. Choices of language, phrasology, etc.

memory

[[Description]]

@@ Keeping in mind what one was about to say.

delivery

[[Description]]

@@ Physical presentation. The use of the voice (intonation), the body (body language), etc.

Dialectic

Definition

The process of discovering and testing knowledge through questions and answers.

Argumentation

Description

Here, argumentation means verbal disputes among two or more parties.

Logic

Description

Logic is mainly concerned with one side of an argument. Such an argument {{I:may}} be face-to-face, but may also be more rhetorical such as that in a book, research paper or lecture.

Argument

{{bookmark( "def.argument" )}}

Definition

A sequence of statements of which one is intended as a conclusion (or finding) and the others, the premises, are claimed to prove or at least provide some evidence for the conclusion.

See Also

<UL>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.consequence" ):consequence}}</LI>

</UL>

Analysis

Description

Analysis begins with Identification. We need to know we have an argument before we can examine it. Identification of an argument can often be difficult. Many arguments are written as if the author were stating raw facts; conversely, many forms of discourse which may seem to be arguments are in fact not. However, there are clues as to what is an argument.

This section begins by describing the various components of an argument; that is the things that all arguments have. Then goes on to discussing how to identifying arguments from a discourse. Next is classifying arguments and finally evaluation of arguments.

See Also

<UL>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.analyze" ):analyze}}</LI>

</UL>

Components

Description

There are two building blocks of arguments, propositions and inference. In turn, within the context of arguments, there are two roles for propositions, premise and conclusion. All arguments contain premises, conclusion and inference.

Propostion

{{bookmark( "def.proposition" )}}

Definition

{{MAIN:

@@ A claim, usually expressed as a declarative sentence, that is either true or false.

}}

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Propositions are the fundamental unit (building block) of arguments.</LI>

<LI>A proposition is not fixed to one particular sequence of words or even one language. The same proposition may be expressed in many different ways.</LI>

<LI>A proposition can be classified by its role in an argument, as a premise or a conclusion.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

{{DEMO:

<UL>

<LI>Dogs do not fly. -- true</LI>

<LI>Snow is red. -- false</LI>

<LI>ET.'s exist. -- unknown, but is either true or false</LI>

</UL>

}}

See Also

<UL>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.assert" ):assert}}</LI>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.affirm" ):affirm}}</LI>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.deny" ):deny}}</LI>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.assent" ):assent}}</LI>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.dissent" ):dissent}}</LI>

</UL>

Premise

{{bookmark( "def.premise" )}}

Definition

A proposition, in the context of an argument, whose role is to prove or at least provide some evidence for the conclusion.

Examples

Premise1: All humans are mortal.

Premise2: Socrates is human.

Conclusion: Socrates is mortal.

Conclusion

{{bookmark( "def.conclusion" )}}

Definition

A proposition, in the context of an argument, whose role is to state the "finding". It's the proposition which states what's being argued, justified or proven.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>The conclusion is often said to 'follow' from the premises.</LI>

</UL>

Inference

{{bookmark( "def.inference" )}}

Definition

The reasoning process expressed by an argument.

Notes

Inference is the glue which binds the propositions of an argument.

Identification

Description

Analysis of an argument begins with Identification. We need to know we have an argument before we can examine it. The way to identify an argument is to find all the components of an argument in a contiguous piece of discourse. Identification of an argument can often be difficult. Many arguments are written as if the author were stating raw facts; conversely, many forms of discourse which may seem to be arguments are in fact not. However, there are clues as to what is an argument. Perhaps the easiest way is by recognizing the presence of the components.

Indicators

Description

An indicator is a word or phrase that clues us in that an argument is being stated. There are two kinds of indicators; those that indicate premises and those that indicate conclusions. The following lists provide the most commonly used indicators.

Premise Indicators

{{bookmark( "def.premise indicator" )}}

Definition

A word or phrase used to introduce a premise.

Examples

In the following, the letter P is used to mark most common ordering of the premise to the associated indicator.

<UL TYPE=SQUARE>

<LI>as P</LI>

<LI>as indicated by P</LI>

<LI>as shown by the fact that P</LI>

<LI>assuming that P</LI>

<LI>because P</LI>

<LI>for P</LI>

<LI>for the reason that P</LI>

<LI>given that P</LI>

<LI>granted that P</LI>

<LI>in that P</LI>

<LI>in view of the fact that P</LI>

<LI>inasmuch as P</LI>

<LI>it is a fact that P</LI>

<LI>may be inferred from P</LI>

<LI>one cannot doubt that P</LI>

<LI>owing to P</LI>

<LI>seeing that P</LI>

<LI>since P</LI>

<LI>the reason is that P</LI>

<LI>this is true because P</LI>

</UL>

Conclusion Indicators

{{bookmark( "def.conclusion indicator" )}}

Definition

A word or phrase used to introduce a conclusion.

Examples

In the following, the letter C is used to mark most common ordering of the conclusion to the associated indicator.

<UL TYPE=SQUARE>

<LI>accordingly C</LI>

<LI>as a result C</LI>

<LI>consequently C</LI>

<LI>as a consequence C</LI>

<LI>as a logical consequence C</LI>

<LI>entails that C</LI>

<LI>for this reason C</LI>

<LI>from which we can infer that C</LI>

<LI>hence C</LI>

<LI>we may conclude C</LI>

<LI>in conclusion C</LI>

<LI>it follows that C</LI>

<LI>it follows necessarily that C</LI>

<LI>so C</LI>

<LI>the moral is C</LI>

<LI>therefore C</LI>

<LI>this being so C</LI>

<LI>thus C</LI>

<LI>we may conclude C</LI>

<LI>we may infer C</LI>

<LI>wherefore C</LI>

<LI>which means that C</LI>

<LI>which proves that C</LI>

</UL>

Hidden

Description

When there are no indicators. It's necessary to analyze what the author is saying. The following may help to provide some assistance in locating the conclusion.

Thesis-Argument

Description

When an argumentative stance is taken, the thesis is usually one of the first things stated. The thesis IS the conclusion; it's what the author intends to prove in the text that follows.

Analytical questions

Description

When there are no indicators and Simple structure-analysis fails. It's necessary to analyze what the author is saying. The following questions will help in that task and also in identifying the parts of the argument.

Questions

<UL>

<LI>What single statement is claimed (implicitly) to follow from the others?</LI>

<LI>What is the arguer trying to prove?</LI>

<LI>What is the main point in the passage?</LI>

</UL>

Classification

Description

All arguments are divided into one of two mutually exclusive categories. Logicians use vastly different techniques to study the arguments of these two categories. Thus, Logic itself is divided into two disciplines which take their names from the categories.

Deduction

{{bookmark( "def.deduction" )}}

Definition

An argument in which it is impossible for the conclusion to be false while the premises are all true.

Examples

@@ {{DEMO:All men are mortal.{{BR}}

Socrates is a man.{{BR}}

therefore, Socrates is a mortal.}}

@@ {{DEMO:If it's raining then the ground is wet.{{BR}}

It's raining.{{BR}}

So, the ground is wet.}}

Notes

Deduction deals with arguments of propositions which are all claimed to have maximal inductive probabilities (i.e. all probabilities are 1.0).

See Also

<UL>

<LI>{{see( "section.deduction" ):Deduction}}</LI>

</UL>

Induction

{{bookmark( "def.induction" )}}

Definition

An argument in which it is possible for the conclusion to be false while all the premises are true.

Examples

@@ Most college students are liberal minded.{{BR}}

Tom is a college student.{{BR}}

Therefore, Tom is liberal minded.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>For every inductive argument at least one of the following holds: 1) At least one premise has a probability (likelihood) associated with it (it is neither absolutely true nor absolutely false such as the premises of a deductive argument). 2) There are unstated premises.</LI>

<LI>In an inductive argument, the arguer is making the claim that although it's possible for the conclusion to be false, given the premises, it's very improbable.</LI>

<LI>If an argument is missing or has unstated premises it is always inductive.</LI>

</UL>

See Also

<UL>

<LI>{{see( "section.induction" ):Induction}}</LI>

</UL>

Tools

Description

For the analysis, and ultimately the evaluation of arguments, logicians have developed various tools to help better understand an argument's content, its physical structure and its inferential structure (train of thought).

Graphical

Description

Most tools for studying an argument are specific to the kind of argument, inductive or deductive. These graphical tools, while limited in the kinds of information they can provide about an argument, will work with all kinds of arguments.

Standard Form

Description

The standard form is perhaps the simplest tool for working with arguments. It's useful for simply understanding an argument (which can sometimes be difficult due to complex or tricky wording). It is also useful for examining an argument to classify it as either deductive or inductive.

The standard form is simple: It's one proposition per line. First list the fundamental premises, then any derived premises and finally the conclusion. It's customary to place a triangle of three dots (âˆ´), read 'therefore', in front of the conclusion.

Examples

All humans are mortal.

Socrates is human.

âˆ´ Socrates is mortal.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Some people prefer to draw a horizontal separating premises from conclusion, as if adding a column of numbers. In this case the 'therefore' symbol is often omitted.</LI>

</UL>

Diagrams

Description

Standard form is usually sufficient for working with simple argument of just two or three premises. However, it's less useful when working with a larger number of premises and a complex inferential structure (an argument involving intermediate conclusions). For such an argument, an {{TERM:argument diagram}} is often more useful.

To begin, each proposition of the argument is numbered. Then the diagram is drawn according to four rules.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Form this set of rules we see the four possible ways in which conclusions can be drawn from premises. That is, there are four possible premise-conclusion relationship patterns.</LI>

</UL>

Vertial Pattern (1:1)

Diagram

A circled number j is placed above a circled number k. An arrow is drawn from j to k.

Semantics

A single premise (j) leads to a single (possibly intermediate) conclusion (k).

Independent Premises (n:1)

Diagram

The circled numbers for the premises P1 through Pn are placed in a row left to right. The circled number for the conclusion C is placed centered below the row of premises. For each premise Pi, an arrows is drawn from Pi to C.

Semantics

Multiple premises (P1) to (Pn) lead to a single conclusion C.

Conjoint Premises (n:1)

Diagram

The circled numbers for the premises P1 through Pn are placed in a row left to right, then collectively underscored by a 'lazy brace' pointing down. The circled number for the conclusion C is placed centered below the row of premises. An arrow is drawn from the tit of the brace to C.

Semantics

Multiple premises P1 through Pn conjointly support a single conclusion C.

Multiple Conclusion (1:n)

Diagram

The circled number for the premise P is placed on top. The circled numbers for the conclusions C1 through Cn are place below from left to right then collectively overscored by a 'lazy brace' pointing up. An arrow is drawn from P to the tit of the brace.

Semantics

A single premise P supports multiple conclusions C1 through Cn.

Symbolic

Description

While graphical tools study the inferential structure of arguments, symbolic tools study patterns of arguments.

Informal

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Critical Thinking</LI>

</UL>

Definition

The study of particular arguments in their natural-language contexts.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>These are arguments written or spoken in a native language such as English.</LI>

</UL>

Formal

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Symbolic Logic</LI>

</UL>

Definition

The study of argument forms. Formal logic studies patterns of reasoning rather than particular arguments.

Examples

Informal

If it's raining then the car is wet.

It's raining.

âˆ´ The car is wet.

Formal

if P then Q.

P.

âˆ´ Q.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>The theory behind formal logic is that an argument is valid if it follows a form that is considered valid.</LI>

<LI>An informal argument or proposition that follows the form of a formal argument or proposition is said to be an 'instance' of the formal counterpart.</LI>

</UL>

Description

This is a relatively little-known but quite intriguing interpretation due to an alternate translation (and perhaps a superior translation) of Aristotle's works. See the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (plato.stanford.edu), square of opposition, section 2.2.

Evaluation

Description

The purpose of an argument is to get to the truth. A factual conclusion is the golden nugget. In evaluating an argument, the goal is to determine how much confidence we can put in the conclusion. How certain we can be that what we've found is not just fool's gold.

Criteria

Description

There are two criteria against which we evaluate a conclusion.

Truth

Description

The probability that the conclusion is in fact true. Ideally, this probability is 100% (absolutely true).

Invulnerability

Description

How well will the conclusion stand up to attack and the advancement of new evidence? Ideally, we want an argument such that no new evidence will affect the conclusion.

Claims

Description

A presenter of an argument makes three claims about the argument.

Inferential Claim

{{bookmark( "def.inferential-claim" )}}

Definition

The claim that there are no errors in the reasoning process used to derive the conclusion.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>The bulk of logic is concerned with this claim.</LI>

</UL>

See Also

<UL>

<LI>{{see( "def.inference" ):Inference}}</LI>

</UL>

Factual Claim

{{bookmark( "def.factual-claim" )}}

Definition

The claim that the premises are true. The audience must agree with the premises, in order to accept the conclusion. If there is doubt about any premises, the arguer then has the further burden of proof for the premises in doubt.

Determination of the truth of particular propositions is {{I:not}} within the realm of logic, but rather in the realm of the topic being discussed.

Relevance Claim

Description

he claim that the premises are relevant to the conclusion.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>It may seem that the claim of relevance is implicitly one aspect of the inferential claim, and indeed it probably is for the lay definition. However, the classical theory of inference does not consider relevance, therefore we list it here as a third claim.</LI>

</UL>

Assessment

Description

In evaluating an argument we consider the claims as requirements for a good argument. The better an argument fulfills those requirements (claims), the more confidence we can have in the conclusion.

The evaluative criteria for a conclusion are assessed indirectly as a function of other more easily obtainable pieces of information: the type of argument (inductive or deductive) and the truth of the factual and inferential claims.

To assess an argument from the classical point of view, first determine if it's deductive or inductive. Next determine if the argument fulfills the factual and inferential claims. Now use the table below to determine what kind of argument you have.

Inferential Factual Assessment

Claim Claim deductive inductive

no --- invalid weak

yes --- valid strong

yes yes sound cogent

For the first and second lines, the factual claim doesn't even come into play. Given this, all sound arguments are valid and all cogent arguments are strong. Since the factual claim doesn't come into play, we can only state for valid and strong arguments that the conclusion is true if the premises are true. All we know is that the reasoning is good.

Invalid and weak arguments are usually not worth bothering with in terms of our confidence in the conclusion. Such arguments may be fruitful in helping to construct better arguments or, in the case of a debate between individuals, such arguments provide much material for exposure of the reasoning flaws.

Valid and strong arguments provide only slightly more confidence in their conclusion. While the truth of the conclusion is not known, if the premises are at least reasonable, then the conclusion is also reasonable. In the case of debate, point out or challenge the bad premise(s).

Sound and cogent arguments are what we strive for. Bottom line, a sound argument is invulnerable to attack. Cogent arguments may be attacked depending upon how the premises and concluding propositions are stated. All inductive arguments are vulnerable to new evidence, though a cogent argument is less so.

Notes

Since this assessment of arguments is classical, it does not consider the relevance of the premises to the conclusion. It is possible to have a sound argument with irrelevant premises. In this case, the argument can still be attacked. In practice an argument's premises must also be relevant to the conclusion to minimize attack.

Deductive Arguments

Invalid

Description

A deductive argument with reasoning errors.

Valid

Description

A deductive argument that is free from reasoning errors.

Sound

Description

A valid argument whose premises are all true. Sound arguments are invulnerable to the introduction of additional evidence. They can only be refuted by attacking the truth of the premises.

Inductive Arguments

Weak

Description

An inductive argument with reasoning errors.

Strong

Description

An inductive argument that is free from reasoning errors.

Cogent

Description

A strong argument with all true premises. Cogent arguments are not invulnerable to attack or the introduction of new information, they only state that their conclusion is likely given the information known.

Refutation

Description

Once an argument is evaluated it can be refuted

Exposition

Description

The most common technique of refuting an argument is to expose a flaw.

Point out a fallacy

Description

Show what's wrong with the argument. One way to do this is to point out the fallacy. However, most people don't know fallacy names so a much better technique is to demonstrate how the argument is flawed (which is often a second argument).

By Proof of Nonconsequence

Definition

An argument proving that a conclusion does not or may not follow from a set of premises.

Counter-Example

Description

A counter-example is the simplest way to demonstrate non-consequence. To refute an argument by counter-example, just show case where the premises can be true while the conclusion is false.

Examples

Argument:

All romances are literature.

All fiction is literature.

âˆ´ All romances are fiction.

Form:

All A are B.

All C are B.

âˆ´ All A are C.

Counterexample:

All cats are animals.

All dogs are animals.

âˆ´ All cats are dogs.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>In applying counterexamples to expose an invalid categorical syllogism it is useful to keep in mind the following set of terms: cats, dogs, mammals, fish and animals.</LI>

</UL>

Fallacies

Definition

A fallacy is a flaw of an erroneous or deceptive argument.

Description

Over time, logicians have cataloged many of the kinds of fallacies. This section presents a catalog organized roughly according to the four claims. Each fallacy is presented in the following format.

<UL>

<LI>Alternate Names<BR>

Other names by which this fallacy is known.</LI>

<LI>Description<BR>

A description of the fallacy.</LI>

<LI>Examples<BR>

Simple examples of the fallacy in use.</LI>

<LI>Exposition<BR>

Hints for exposing the fallacy.</LI>

</UL>

Fallacies of Arguments

Description

This section is a catalog of fallacies. They are organized according to which claim they fail to meet. Each fallacy in the catalog begins with a list of alternate names that it's known by (if any), then a short description, followed by some examples of the fallacy, and finally a list of techniques for exposing the fallacy. If the exposition section is not present the fallacy can probably be exposed with a counter-example, this is particularly true for most fallacies relating to form.

Factual Claim

Description

Fallacies which call into question the truth of one or more questions.

Factual Problems

Description

Premises which give rise to questions about how well they fulfill the factual claim. This includes items which are only partially factual and those that spark concerns in the way they present the facts.

For an argument to be convincing, one major component is that the audience accepts the premises as true. These premises raise questions about the factual nature of one or more premises.

False Fact

Description

A premise is not factual.

Fake Precision

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>False Precision</LI>

<LI>Misplaced Precision</LI>

<LI>Spurious Accuracy</LI>

</UL>

Description

A common form of false premise. Occurs when an argument treats information as more precise than it really is. This happens when imprecise information contained in the premises must be taken as precise in order to adequately support the conclusion.

Unestablished

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Untestable</LI>

</UL>

Definition

The theory advanced to explain why some phenomenon occurs has not been established or cannot be tested.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Aircraft in the mid-Atlantic disappear because of the effect of the Bermuda Triangle, a force so subtle it cannot be measured on any instrument.</LI>

<LI>I won the lottery because my psychic aura made me win.</LI>

<LI>The reason why everything exists is that god created it.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the theory. Show that it makes no predictions, or that the predictions it does make cannot ever be wrong, even if the theory is false.

Listener Doubt/Disagreement

Description

Not really a fallacy, but an argument is pretty much meaningless if your listener doesn't believe your premises.

Hearsay

Definition

The arguer uses as a premise information they got from someone else. This fallacy typically occurs in an argument where someone is reasoning from events that have happened. The problem with this is that the information is second-hand. We don't know if the arguer got the information exactly right, we are unable to attack the premise effectively simply because the arguer cannot fairly defend it.

Formal Problems

Description

These fallacy involves either premises of multiple propositions or a single compound proposition. In either case, no particular fact is wrong, however the way the propositions are assembled (usually through the use of logical operation, 'and', 'or', 'if...then') leads to a fallacious statement or implication.

Problems with 'AND'

Inconsistency

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Contradictory Premises</LI>

</UL>

Definition

Illegitimate use of the 'and' operator. The arguer asserts a premise that cannot be true because it contradicts itself, or a set of premises that cannot all be true because they contradict each other. In such a case, the propositions may be contradictories or they may be contraries.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Montreal is about 200km from Ottawa, while Toronto is 400km from Ottawa. Toronto is closer to Ottawa than Montreal.</LI>

<LI>John is taller than Jake, and Jake is taller than Fred, while Fred is taller than John.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Assume that one of the statements is true, and then use it as a premise to show that one of the other statements is false.

Plurium Interrogationum

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Many Questions</LI>

<LI>Complex Question</LI>

<LI>Fallacy of interrogation</LI>

<LI>Fallacy of presupposition</LI>

</UL>

Definition

An illegitimate use of the 'and' operator. Two otherwise unrelated points are conjoined and treated as a single proposition. The reader is expected to accept or reject both together, when in reality one is acceptable while the other is not.

Occurs when someone demands a simple (or simplistic) answer to a complex question.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Do you support freedom and the right to bear arms?</LI>

<LI>Have you stopped using illegal sales practices?</LI>

<LI>You should support home education and the God-given right of parents to raise their children according to their own beliefs.</LI>

<LI>Are higher taxes an impediment to business or not? Yes or no?</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the two propositions illegitimately conjoined and show that believing one does not mean that you have to believe the other.

Loaded Question

Description

When someone asks a question "loaded" with a false presupposition.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Have you stopped beating your wife?</LI>

</UL>

Problems with 'OR'

False Dilemma

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>False Dichotomy</LI>

<LI>Bifurcation</LI>

<LI>False Dilemma</LI>

<LI>Black-and-White Fallacy</LI>

<LI>Bogus Dilemma</LI>

<LI>Either/Or Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Illegitimate use of the 'or' operator. Arguer offers a limited number of options (usually two), while in reality there are more options.

The false assumption is made that only one of a number of alternative holds. @Ref(Varzi)

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Either you're for me or against me.</LI>

<LI>America: love it or leave it.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the options given and show (with an example) that there is an additional option.</LI>

</UL>

Problems with 'IF...THEN...'

Slippery Slope

Description

An illegitimate use of the 'if-then' operator. In order to show that a proposition P is unacceptable, a sequence of increasingly unacceptable events is shown to follow from P.

Occurs when the conclusion of an argument rests upon an alleged chain reaction, suggesting that a single step in the wrong direction will result in a disastrous or otherwise undesirable outcome. Its form is:

A1 -> A2

A2 -> A3

...

An -> An+1

It should not be the case that An+1.

âˆ´ It should not be the case that An.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>If I make an exception for you then I have to make an exception for everyone.</LI>

<LI>You should never gamble. Once you start gambling you find it hard to stop. Soon you are spending all your money on gambling, and eventually you will turn to crime to support your earnings.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the proposition P being refuted and identify the final event in the series of events. Then show that this final event need not occur as a consequence of P.

Semantic Slippery Slope

Causal Slippery Slope

Constructive & Destructive Dilemmas

Description

Many dilemma arguments take one of two forms, the {{I:constructive}} or {{I:destructive}} dilemma.

Constructive Dilemma

(P â†’ Y) âˆ§ (Q â†’ Z)

P âˆ¨ Q

âˆ´ Y âˆ¨ Z

Destructive Dilemma

(P â†’ Y) âˆ§ (Q â†’ Z)

Â¬Y âˆ¨ Â¬Z

âˆ´ Â¬P âˆ¨ Â¬Q

Exposition

There are two ways to attach these arguments:

<UL>

<LI>Grasping by the horns<BR>

Expose the fallacy by attacking the conjunction of the first premise. Proceed by proving the conjunctive premise false by proving either conjunct false.</LI>

<LI>Escaping between the horns<BR>

Expose the fallacy by attacking the disjunction of the second premise. Proceed by proving the disjunctive premise false.</LI>

</UL>

Premises of Definition

Description

In order to make our words or concepts clear, we use definitions. The purpose of a definition is to site exactly what a word means. A good definition should enable a reader to 'pick out' instances of the word or concept with no outside help.

Too Broad

Description

The definition includes items which should not be included.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>An apple is something which is red and round. (So is Mars)</LI>

<LI>A figure is square if and only if it has four sides of equal length. (So do trapezoids)</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the term being defined. Identify the conditions in the definition. Find an item which meets the condition but is obviously not an instance of the term.

Too Narrow

Description

The definition does not include items which should be included.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>An apple is something which is red and round. (But Golden Delicious apples are yellow)</LI>

<LI>A book is pornographic if and only if it contains pictures of naked people. (What about pornographic novels without pictures?)</LI>

<LI>Something is music if and only if it is played on a piano. (So a violin does not play music?)</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the term being defined. Identify the conditions in the definition. Find an item which is an instance of the term but does not meet the conditions.

Failure to Elucidate

Description

The definition is harder to understand than the term being defined.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Someone is lascivious if and only if he is wanton.</LI>

<LI>An object is beautiful if and only if it is aesthetically successful.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the term being defined. Identify the conditions in the definition. Show that the conditions are more clearly defined then the term being defined.

Circular Definition

Description

The definition includes the term being defined as a part of the definition.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>An aminal is human if and only if it has human parents.</LI>

<LI>A book is pornographic if and only if it contains pornography.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the term being defined. Identiify the conditions in the definition. Show that at least one term used in the conditions is the same as the term being defined.

Conflicting Conditions

Description

The definition is self-contradictory.

Examples

A society is free if and only if liberty is maximized and people are required to take responsibility for their actions.

People are eligible to apply for a learner's permit (to drive) if they have (a) no previous driving experience, (b) access to a vehicle, and (c) experience operating a motor vehicle.

Relevance Claim

Description

Occur when there is a problem between the relevance of the premises to the conclusion. Most such arguments may be called 'non secuiturs' (latin, it does not follow).

Often used intentionally to divert attention from the subject.

Petitio Principii

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Begging the Question</LI>

<LI>Request for the source</LI>

</UL>

Description

The arguer creates the illusion that inadequate premises provide adequate support for the conclusion by leaving out a key premise, by restating the conclusion as a premise, or by reasoning in a circle. After reading or hearing the argument, the observer is inclined to ask, "But how do you know X?" where X is the needed support.

Assume the conclusion

Description

The premise of an argument merely states the conclusion in slightly different language.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Capital punishment is justified for the crimes of murder and kidnapping because it is quite legitimate and appropriate that someone be put ot death for having committed such hateful and inhuman acts.</LI>

<LI>Anyone who preaches revolution has a vision of the future for the simple reason that if a person has no vision of the future he could not possibly preach revolution.</LI>

</UL>

Curcurlus in Probando

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Circular Argument</LI>

<LI>Vicious Circle</LI>

</UL>

Description

The conclusion restates the premise after a chain of inferences.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Ford Motor Company clearly produces the finest car in the United States. We know they produce the finest cars because they have the best design engineers. This is true because they can afford to pay them more than other manufacturers. Obviously they can afford to pay them more because they produce the finest cars in the United States.</LI>

<LI>Either you're for us or against us. You're obviously not for us. So, you're against us.</LI>

<LI>Since I'm not lying, it follows that I'm telling the truth.</LI>

<LI>We know that God exists, since the Bible says God exists. What the Bible says must be true, since God wrote it and God never lies. (Here, we must agree that God exists in order to believe that God wrote the Bible.)</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>Either it's hot or it's cold. It's not cold. So, it's hot.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that in order to believe that the premises are true we must already agree that the conclusion is true.

Appeals to Irrelevant Attributes of the Proponent

Description

fallacy of irrelevancy involving the origins or history of an idea. It is fallacious to either endorse or condemn an idea based on its past--rather than on its present--merits or demerits, unless its past in some way affects its present value. For example, the origin of evidence can be quite relevant to its evaluation, especially in historical investigations. The origin of testimony--whether first hand, hearsay, or rumor--carries weight in evaluating it.

In contrast, the value of any scientific ideas can be objectively evaluated by established techniques, so that the origin or history of the idea is irrelevant to its value. For example, the chemist Kekule claimed to have discovered the ring structure of the benzene molecule during a dream of a snake biting its own tail. While this fact is psychologically interesting, it is neither evidence for nor against the hypothesis that benzene has a ring structure, which had to be tested for correctness.

Ad Hominem

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Appeal against the Person</LI>

</UL>

Description

Attempt to discredit a claim or proposal by attacking its proponents (diverting attention from the argument).

Abusive

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum Ad hominem abusive</LI>

<LI>Style Over Substance</LI>

</UL>

Description

Attack a person's age, character, family, gender, ethnicity, social or economic status, personality, appearance, dress, behavior or professional, political or religious affiliations.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Nixon lost the presidential debate because of the sweat on his forehead.</LI>

<LI>Trudeau knows how to move a crowd. He must be right.</LI>

<LI>Why don't you take the advice of that nicely dressed young man?</LI>

<LI>Jones advocates fluoridation.{{BR}}

Jones is a convicted thief.{{BR}}

âˆ´ We should not fluoridate.<LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the attack and show that the character or circumstances of the person has nothing to do with the truth or falsity of the proposition being defended.

Circumstantial

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum Ad hominem circumstantial</LI>

</UL>

Description

An attempt to refute a claim (or divert attention from the real issue) by attacking not it's proponent, but the proponent's circumstances including beliefs, affiliation, association or assumptions.

The ad hominem circumstantial is easy to recognize because it always takes this form:

Of course Mr. X argues this way; just look at the circumstances that affect him.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>We should disregard Share B.C.'s argument because they are being funded by the logging industry.</LI>

<LI>Jones advocates fluoridation.{{BR}}

Jones hangs around criminals.{{BR}}

âˆ´ We should not fluoridate.</LI>

<LI>Jones supports fluoridation.{{BR}}

Jones own's a fluoridation firm.{{BR}}

âˆ´ We should not fluoridate.</LI>

<LI>Jones denys superstition.{{BR}}

He says breaking a mirror is bad.{{BR}}

âˆ´ breaking a mirror is probably bad.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the attack and show that the character or circumstances of the person has nothing to do with the truth or falsity of the proposition being defended.

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Sometimes this is called 'Guilt by Association Fallacy', but only when it refers to the associations held by the arguer.</LI>

</UL>

Guilt by Association

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Bad Company Fallacy</LI>

<LI>The Company that You Keep Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

his fallacy has the following form:

Person P accepts idea I.

âˆ´ I must be wrong. (Since nobody want's to be associated with P).

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Hitler was in favor of euthanasia. Therefore, euthanasia is wrong.</LI>

<LI>The Nazis favored eugenics. So, eugenics is wrong.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>Hitler was a vegetarian. So, vegetarianism is wrong.</LI>

<LI>The Nazis were conservationists. So, conservationism is wrong.</LI>

</UL>

Tu Quoque

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>You too</LI>

</UL>

Description

Refute a claim by attacking its proponent on the grounds that he or she is a hypocrite (not practice what he preaches), upholds a double standard of conduct, or is selective and therefore inconsistent in enforcing a principle.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>You say I shouldn't drink, but you haven't been sober for more than a year.</LI>

<LI>Jones believes we shouldn't drink.<BR>

Jones is an alcoholic.<BR>

âˆ´ We shouldn't abstain from liquor.<BR>

@ref(Varzi)</LI>

Exposition

Identify the attack and show that the character or circumstances of the person has nothing to do with the truth or falsity of the proposition being defended.

Situational Fallacies

Description

Arguments in support of or against someone by brining up their situation.

Ad Misercordiam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad misercordiam</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Pity</LI>

</UL>

Description

Such arguments ask us to excuse or forgive an action on the grounds of extenuating circumstances. They seek clemency for breaches of duty, or sympathy for someone whose poor conduct or noncompliance with a rule is already established. An appeal to pity may be either legitimate or fallacious, depending on whether or not the allegedly extenuating circumstances are genuinely relvant to the case.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>We hope you'll accept our recommendations. We spend the last three months working extra time on it.</LI>

<LI>Oh, officer, you see my baby here was crying for some candy and I took her to the candy store before I came back to my car.<BR>

âˆ´ Therefore, you shouldn't give me a parking ticket.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the proposition and the appeal to pity and argue that the pitiful state of the arguer has nothing to do with the truth of the proposition.

Age

Ad Novitatem

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad novitatem</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the new(er)</LI>

</UL>

Description

The fallacy of asserting that something is better or more correct simply because it is new, or newer than something else.

Example

<UL>

<LI>BeOS is a far better choice of operating system than OpenStep, as it has a much newer design.</LI>

</UL>

Ad Antiquitatem

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad antiquitatem</LI>

<LI>Appeal to antiquity</LI>

<LI>Appeal to tradition</LI>

</UL>

Description

Something is said to be right or good because it is old.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>"For thousands of years Christians have believed in Jesus. Christianity must be true, to have persisted so long even in the face of persecution."</LI>

</UL>

Social Class

Ad Crumenam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad crumenam</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the wealthy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Believe that those with more money are more likely to be right.

Example

<UL>

<LI>Microsoft software is undoubtedly superior; why else would Bill Gates have got so rich?</LI>

</UL>

Ad Lazarum

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad lazarum</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the poor</LI>

</UL>

Description

Statement that someone poor is sounder or more virtuous than someone wealthier.

Example

<UL>

<LI>Monks are more likely to possess insight into the meaning of life, as they have given up the distractions of wealth.</LI>

</UL>

Ad Verecundiam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad verecundiam</LI>

<LI>Appeal to (unqualified) Authority</LI>

<LI>Argument from Authority</LI>

<LI>Ipse Dixit</LI>

</UL>

Description

While sometimes it may be appropirate to cite an authority to support a point, often it is not. In particular, an appeal to authority is inappropriate if:

<UL>

<LI>The person is not qualified to have an expert opinion on the subject.</LI>

<LI>Experts in the field disagree on this issue.</LI>

<LI>The authority was making a joke, drunk, or otherwise not being serious.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Noted psychologist Dr. Frasier Crane recommends that you buy the EZ-Rest Hot Tub.</LI>

<LI>Economist John Kenneth Galbraith argues that a tight money policy is the best cure for a recession.</LI>

<LI>

My teacher says that I should be proud to be an American.

âˆ´ Therefore, I should be proud to be an American.

(Varzi)</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Show that either 1. the person cited is not an authority in the field, or that 2. there is general disagreement among the experts in the field on this point.</LI>

</UL>

... Anonymous

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad verecundiam, anonymous</LI>

</UL>

Description

<UL>

<LI>The authority in question is not named.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>A government official said today that the new gun law will be proposed tomorrow.</LI>

<LI>Experts agree that the best way to prevent nuclear war is to prepare for it.</LI>

<LI>It is held that there are more than two million needless operations conducted every year.</LI>

<LI>Rumor has it that the Prime Minister will declare another holiday in October.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Argue that because we dont' know the source of the information we have no way to evaluation the reliability of the information.</LI>

</UL>

Appeal to Rumor

Ad Populum

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum Ad Populum</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the People/Popularity</LI>

</UL>

Description

A proposition is held to be true because it is widly held to be true or is held to be true by some (usually upper crust) sector of the population. This is an appeal to emotion because it creates the fear or thought in the listener's mind that he doesn't want to be left behind. The basic structure of the ad populum is:

You want to be accepted/included-in-the-group/loved/esteemed...Therefore, you should accept XYZ as true.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Everyone knows that the earth is flat, so why do you persist in your outlandish claims?</LI>

<LI>If you were beautiful, you could live like this, so buy Buty-EZ and become beautiful.</LI>

<LI>

Everyone believes premarital sex is wrong.

âˆ´ Premarital sex is wrong.

</LI>

<LI>

Discriminating palates prefer wine brand X.

âˆ´ You should drink wine brand X.

</LI>

</UL>

direct

Description

In the direct form of ad populum, the arguer attempts to rouse the croud to create the 'sheep or mob mentality' for purposes of convincing. Since people don't want to be 'left out', they will often accept the conclusions of the speeker without real evidence.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Aldolf Hitler was a master at this.</LI>

<LI>Peer pressure.</LI>

</UL>

indirect

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Bandwagon argument</LI>

</UL>

Description

The arguer claims that everybody's doing it.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Of course you want to buy Zing toothpaste. Why, 90 percent of America brushes with Zing.</LI>

</UL>

Hearsay

Description

A variation is hearsay, which depends upon second or third hand sources.

Appeal to Emotion

Ad Baculum

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad baculum</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the stick</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Force</LI>

</UL>

Description

Threats or intimidation. The reader is told that unpleasant consequences will follow if they do not agree with the author.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>You had better agree that the new company policy is the best beet if you expect to keep your job.</LI>

<LI>

If you dont' vote for me, I'll break your leg.

âˆ´ You ought to vote for me.

</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the threat and the proposition and agree that the threat is unrelated to the truth or falsity of the proposition.</LI>

</UL>

Ad Invidiam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad invidiam</LI>

<LI>Appeal to envy</LI>

</UL>

Ad Metum

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad Metum</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Fear</LI>

</UL>

Ad Odium

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad Odium</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Hatred</LI>

</UL>

Ad Superbium

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad Superbium</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Pride</LI>

</UL>

Ad Consequentiam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad consequentiam</LI>

<LI>Appeal to the consequence</LI>

</UL>

Description

<UL>

<LI>The author points out the the disagreeable consequence of holding a particular belief in order to show that this belief is false.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>You can't agree that evolution is true, because if it were, then we would be no better than monkeys and apes.</LI>

<LI>You must believe in God, for otherwise life would have no meaning.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the consequences to and argue that what we want to be the case does not affect what is in fact the case.</LI>

</UL>

Appeal to Vanity/Snobbery

Description

Associtates the product with someone who is admired, pursued, or imitated, the ida being that you, too, will be admired and pursued if you use it.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The few, the Proud, the marines.</LI>

</UL>

Divine Fallacy

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argument from incredulity.</LI>

</UL>

Description

Arguing that because you can't explain something or that something is unexplainable given current knowledge/technology, that it must be an act of god, divinity, paranormal phenomenon or "UFO".

Pragmatic Fallacy

Description

Committed when one argues that something is true because it works. (Eg. Astrology, numerology, etc.)

Ad Ignorantiam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum Ad Ignorantiam</LI>

<LI>Argument from Ignorance</LI>

<LI>Appeal to Ignorance</LI>

</UL>

Description

Has one of the following two forms:

It has not been proved that P.

âˆ´ It is not the case that P.

or

It has not been proved that not-P.

âˆ´ P.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Since you cannot prove that ghosts do not exist, they must exist.</LI>

<LI>

No one has ever proved that God exists.

âˆ´ God does not exist.

@@

No one has every proved that God does not exist.

âˆ´ God exists.

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the proposition in question. Argue that it may be true even though we don't know whether it is or isn't.</LI>

</UL>

Burden of Proof

Description

The burden of proof is always on the person asserting something. Shifting the burden of proof is the fallacy of putting the burden of proof on the person who denies or questions the assertion. The source of the fallacy is the assumption that something is true unless proven otherwise. (a special case of ad ignorantiam)

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Ok, so if you don't think the grey aliens have gained control of the US government, can you prove it?</LI>

</UL>

God of the Gaps

Description

Refers to a view of God deriving from a theistic position in which anything that can be explained by human knowledge is not in the domain of God, so the role of God is therefore confined to the gaps in scientific explanations of nature.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>An infinite regress is impossible, therefore there must have been a prime mover of the universe; namely God.</LI>

</UL>

Prejudicial Language

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Prejudicial Language</LI>

</UL>

Description

<UL>

<LI>Loaded or emotive terms are used to attach value or moral goodness to believing the proposition.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Right thinking Canadians will agree with me that we should have another free vote on capital punishment.</LI>

<LI>A reasonable person would agree that our income statement is too low.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the prejudicial terms used (eg. "right thinking Canadians"). Show that disagreeing with the conclusion does not make a person "wrong thinking".</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Often the word "proof" is added to an inductive argument to make it appear soundly deductive.</LI>

</UL>

Ad Nauseam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum ad nauseam</LI>

</UL>

Description

Belief that an assertion is more likely to be true, or more likely to be accepted as true, the more often it is heard.

Wishful Thinking

Description

Takes the form:

I want P to be true..

âˆ´ P is true.

Appeal to Nature

Alterante Names

<UL>

<LI>Natural Law Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Of course homosexuality is unnatural. When's the last time you saw two animals of the same sex mating?"</LI>

</UL>

Straw Man

Description

An attempt to refute a claim by confusing it with a less plausible claim and then attacking that less plausible claim instead of addressing the original issue.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>People who opposed the Charlottown Accord probably just wanted Quebec to separate. But we want Quebec to stay in Canada.</LI>

<LI>We should have conscription. People cdon't what to enter the military because they find it an inconvenience. But they should realize that there are more important things than convenience.</LI>

<LI>

There can be no truth if everything is relative.

âˆ´ Einstein's theory of relativity cannot be true.

</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that the opposition's argument has been misrepresented by showing that the opposition has a stronger argument. Describe the stronger argument.

Red Herring

Description

Intentionally divert attention away from the subject.

Two Wrongs Make a Right

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The operation cost just under $500, and no one was killed, or even hurt. In that same time the Pentagon spend tens of millions of dollars and dropped tens of thousands of pounds of explosives on Viet Nam, killing or wounding thousands of human beings, causing hundreds of millions of dollars of damage. Because nothing justified their actions in our calculus, nothing could contradict the merit of ours.</LI>

</UL>

Dicto Simpliciter

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Accident</LI>

<LI>Sweeping Generalization</LI>

<LI>A Dicto simpliciter Ad Dictum Secundum Quid</LI>

</UL>

Description

A general rule is misapplied to a specific cast it was not indended to cover. This rule is the irrelevant to the argument.

A fallacy of the following form:

Xs are normally Ys.

c is an X. (Where c is abnormal)

âˆ´ c is a Y.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Birds normally can fly. Tweety the Penguin is a bird. So, Tweety can fly.</LI>

<LI>The law says that you should not travel faster than 65mph, thus even though your father could not breathe, you should not have travelled faster than 65mph.</LI>

<LI>It is good to return things you have borrowed. Therefore, you should return this automatic rifle from the madman you borrowed it from.</LI>

<LI>Christians generally dislike atheists. You are a christian, so you must dislike atheists.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

<UL>

<LI>Identify the generalization in question and show that it is not a universal generalization. Then show that the circumstances of this case suggest that the generalization ought not to apply.</LI>

</UL>

Inferential Fallacies

Fallacies of Deductive Rules

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Formal Fallacies</LI>

</UL>

Description

A formal fallacy is based solely on logical form. It is committed when someone uses a valid deductive inference rule incorrectly or when someone 'invents' an invalid inference rule.

Syllogistic Fallacies

Description

Involves an illicit rule of deduction applied to a syllogism.

Existential Fallacy

Description

A standard form categorical syllogism with two universal premises has a particular conclusion.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All mice are animals, and all animals are dangerous, so some mice are dangerous.</LI>

<LI>No honest people steal, and all honest people pay taxes, so some honest people pay taxes.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Assume that the premises are true, but that there are no instances of the category described. For example, in 1. above, assume there are no mice, and in 2. above, assume there are no honest people. This shows that the conclusion is false.

Exclusive Premises

Alternative Names

<UL>

<LI>Two Negative Premises</LI>

<LI>Exclusive Premises</LI>

</UL>

Description

<UL>

<LI>Any categorical syllogism with two negative premises.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>No moslems are christians. No jews are moslems. So, no jews are christians.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>No reptiles are mammals. No dogs are reptiles. So, no dogs are mammals.</LI>

</UL>

Undistributed Middle

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Undistributed Middle Term</LI>

</UL>

Description

<UL>

<LI>Any form of categorical syllogism in which the middle term is not distributed at least once.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All communists are liberals. All democrats are liberals. So, all democrats are communists.</LI>

</UL>

Illicit Process

Description

Any form of categorical syllogism in which a term which is distributed in the conclusion is undistributed in a premise

Illicit Major

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Illicit Process of the Major Term</LI>

</UL>

Description

Any form of categorical syllogism in which the major term is distributed in the conclusion, but not in the major premise.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All communists are leftists. No conservatives are communists. So, no conservatives are leftists.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>All dogs are animals. No cats are dogs. So, no cats are animals.</LI>

<LI>All Texans are Americans, and no Californians are Texans, therefore, no Californians are Americans.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that there may be other members of the predicate category not mentioned in the premises which are contrary to the conclusion.

Illicit Minor

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Illicit Process of the Minor Term</LI>

</UL>

Description

Any form of categorical syllogism in which the minor term is distributed in the conclusion but not in the minor premise.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All terrorists are extremists. All extremists are radicals. So, all radicals are terrorists.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>All whales are mammals. All mammals are animals. So, all animals are whales.</LI>

</UL>

Illicit Affirmative/Negative

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Affirmative Conclusion from Negative Premises</LI>

<LI>Negative Conclusion from Affirmative Premises</LI>

</UL>

Description

Any form of categorical syllogism with a negative conclusion and affirmative premises.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All sound arguments are valid. Some fallacious arguments are sound. So, some fallacious arguments are not valid.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>All dogs are animals. Some pets are dogs. So, some pets are not animals.</LI>

</UL>

Syllogistic Fallacy

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise</LI>

</UL>

Description

Any form of categorical syllogism with an affirmative conclusion and at least one negative premise.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All judges are politicians. Some lawyers are not judges. Therefore, some lawyers are politicians.</LI>

<LI>All mice are animals, and some animals are not dangerous, therefore some mice are dangerous.</LI>

<LI>No honest people steal, and all honest people pay taxes, so some people who steal pay taxes.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>All whales are mammals. Some fish are not whales. Therefore, some fish are mammals</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Assume that the premises are true. Find an example which allows the premises to be true but which clearly contradicts the conclusion.

Illicit Transform

Illicit Conversion

Description

Treating the contraposition of an A or O proposition as an immediate inference.

Illicit Contraposition

Description

Treating the contraposition of an E or I proposition as an immediate inference.

Propositional Logic

Description

Involves an illicit rule of deduction applied to a truth-functional operator.

Affirming a Disjunct

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Affirming One Disjunct</LI>

<LI>The Fallacy of the Alternate Syllogism</LI>

<LI>Asserting an Alternative</LI>

<LI>Improper Disjunctive Syllogism</LI>

</UL>

Description

Or is used exclusively though logic defines it as inclusive. This fallacy has the followng form.

P or Q.

P.

âˆ´ not Q.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Today is Saturday or Sunday.{{BR}}

Today is Saturday.{{BR}}

âˆ´ Today is not Sunday.</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>As with other propositional fallacies, an argument which affirms a disjunct is most likely to seem valid when we take into consideration some further information not explicitly mentioned in the argument. In the case of affirming a disjunct, this is:

implied premise: Not both P and Q.

</LI>

<LI>If we have some reason to believe that the two disjuncts are contraries, then the argument may be a valid enthymeme. In contrast, if we cannot rule out the truth of both disjuncts, then the argument is fallacious.</LI>

</UL>

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Today is Saturday or Sunday. Today is Saturday. So, today is not Sunday.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

In common language 'OR' is either inclusive or exclusive. As a form of argument, Affirming One Disjunct is perfectly valid for the exclusive sense of 'OR'. It is only for the inclusive sense that it is fallacious. For this reason, there is a problem of ambiguity of the two forms, which faces the application of Affirming One Disjunct as a fallacy. In order to accuse an argument of committing this fallacy, we must sdetermine in which sense the 'or' in the first premise is used.

Affirming the Consequent

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Asserting the Consequent</LI>

<LI>Affirmation of the Consequent</LI>

</UL>

Description

Fallacies of the form:

if P then Q.

Q

âˆ´ P

Examples

<UL>

<LI>If it's raining, the streets will be wet. The streets are wet. So, it's raining.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

If it's snowing, the streets will be covered with snow. The streets are covered with snow. So, it's snowing.

Commutation of Conditionals

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Converting a Conditional</LI>

<LI>The Fallacy of the Consequent</LI>

</UL>

Description

Argument takes the form:

if A then B.

âˆ´ if B then A.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>If James is a bachelor, then he is unmarried. So, If he's unmarried, then he's a bachelor.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>If James is President, then he is over 35. So, if James is over 35, then he is president.</LI>

</UL>

Denying a Conjunct

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>The Fallacy of the Disjunctive Syllogism</LI>

</UL>

Description

Of the form:

Not both P and Q

Not P

âˆ´ Q

Examples

<UL>

<LI>It isn't both sunny and overcast. It isn't sunny. It's overcast.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>It isn't both raining and snowing. It isn't raining. It's snowing.</LI>

</UL>

Denying the Antecedent

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Denial of the Antecedent</LI>

</UL>

Description

Any argument of the following form is invalid:

if A then B

not A

âˆ´ not B

Examples

<UL>

<LI>If you get hit by a car when you are six then you will die young. But you were not hit by a car when you were six. Thus you will not die young.</LI>

<LI>If I am in Calgary then I am in Alberta. I am not in Calgary, thus, I am not in Alberta.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>If it's raining, then the streets are wet. It isn't raining. So, the streets aren't wet.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that even though the premises are true, the conclusion may be false. In particular, show that the consequence B may occur even though A does not occur.

Together with Affirming the Consequent, this is a fallacy which involves either confusion about the direction of a conditional relation, or a conflating of a conditional with a biconditional proposition.

Improper Transposition

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Negating Antecedent and Consequent</LI>

</UL>

Description

Fallacy of the form:

If P then Q.

âˆ´ If not P then not Q.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>If there's a fire, then there's smoke. So, if there's no fire, then there's no smoke.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>If we guillotine the king, then he will die. So, if we don't guillotine the king, then he won't die.</LI>

</UL>

Quantified Logic

Description

Involves an illicit rule of deduction applied to a quantifier.

Illicit Converstion

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>False Conversion</LI>

</UL>

Description

Syllogisms of the form:

All P are Q.

âˆ´ All Q are P.

or

Some P are not Q.

âˆ´ Some Q are not P.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All comunists are atheists. So, all atheises are communists.</LI>

<LI>Some dogs are not pets. So, some pets are not dogs.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>All dogs are mammals. So, all mammals are dogs.</LI>

<LI>Some mammals are not cats. So, some cats are not mammals.</LI>

</UL>

Quantifier Shift

Some Are/Some Are Not

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Unwarranted Contrast</LI>

</UL>

Description

Fallacies of the form:

Some S are P

âˆ´ Some S are not P.

or

Some S are not P.

âˆ´ Some S are P.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Some politicians are crooks. So, some politicians are not crooks.{{BR}}

'some' means anywhere from 1 to all. And since it's possible that it refers to all, the conclusion cannot be true.</LI>

</UL>

Fallacies involving Identity

Illicit Substitution of Identicals

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Masked Man Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Fallacies of the form

a = b

Ca

âˆ´ Cb

or

Ca

Not Cb

âˆ´ not a = b

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The witness claims that the masked man committed the crime. The witness denies that Mr. Hyde committed the crime. Therefore, Mr. Hyde is not the masked man.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

The witness claims that the masked man committed the crime. The masked man is Mr. Hyde. Thereforme, the witness claims that Mr. Hyde committed the crime.

Fallacies of Induction

Alternate Name

<UL>

<LI>Weak Induction</LI>

</UL>

Description

Occur when the inductive probability of an argument (i.e. The probability of its conclusion given its premises) is low, or at least lower than the arguer thinks it is.

Relating to Structure

Description

Occur when the author mistakenly assumes that the whole is nothing more than the sum of its parts. However, things joined together may have different properties as a whole than any of them do separately.

Composition

Description

Occurs when we invalidly impute characteristics of one or more parts of a thing to the whole of which they are parts.

Form:

P1, ..., Pn are parts of W.

P1, ..., Pn have property F.

âˆ´ W has property F.

Example

<UL>

<LI>The brick wall is six feet tall. Thus, the bricks in the wall are six feet tall.</LI>

<LI>Germany is a militant country. Thus, each German is militant.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

The human body is made up of atoms, which are invisible. So, The body is invisible.

Exposition

Show that the properties in question are properties of the whole, and not of each part or member of the whole. If necessary, describe the parts to show that they could not have the properties of the whole.

Division

Description

If something has property F, Then its parts are attributed with property F.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The universe has existed for fifteen billion years. The universe is made out of molecules. So, each of the molecules in the universe has existed for fifteen billion years.</LI>

<LI>Each brick is three inches high, thus, the brick wall is three inches high.</LI>

<LI>Because the brain is capable of consciousness, each neural cell in the brain must be capable of consciousness.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

People are made out of atoms. People are visible. So, atoms are visible.

Exposition

Whow that the properties in question are the properties of the parts, and not of the whole. If necessary, describe the parts to show that they couldn not have the properties of the whole.

Ad Logicam

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Argumentum Ad Logicam</LI>

<LI>Fallacy Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Argument that a proposition is false because it has been presented as the conclusion of a fallacious argument.

Non Causa Pro Causa

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>False Cause</LI>

</UL>

Description

What is common to all false-cause fallacies is that their conclusions are causal claims which are inadequately supported by their premises.

Cum Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc

Description

Fallacious inference that a causal relationship exists merely because two events happenned together.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Literacy rates have steadily declined since the advent of television. Clearly television viewing impedes learning.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>The begger a child's shoe size, the better the child's handwriting. So, having big feet must make it easier to write.</LI>

</UL>

Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>post hoc</LI>

</UL>

Description

Fallacious inference that, a causal relationship exists merely because one event happenned before the other.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Immigration to Alberta from Ontario increased. Soon after, the welfare rolls increased. Therefore, the increased immigration caused the increased welfare rolls.</LI>

<LI>I took EZ-No-Cold, and two days later, my cold disappeared.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Example

<UL>

<LI>Roosters crow just before the sun rises. So, roosters crowing cause the sun to rise.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that the correlation is coincidental by showing that: 1. the effect would have occurred even if the cause did not occur, or 2. that the effect was caused by something other than the suggested cause.

Joint Effect

Definition

One thing is held to cause another when in fact both are the effect of a single underlying cause. This fallacy is often understood as a special case of post hoc ergo prompter hoc.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>We are experienceing high unemployment which is being caused by a low consumer demand. (In fact, both may be caused by high interest rates.)</LI>

<LI>You have a fever and this is causing you to break out in spots. (In fact, both symptoms are cause by the measles).</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the two effects and show that they are caused by the same underlying cause. It is necessary to describe the underlying cause and prove that it causes each symptom.

Wrong Direction

Description

The relation between cause and effect is reversed.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Cancer causes smoking.</LI>

<LI>The increase in AIDS was caused by more sex education.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Give a causal argument showing that the relation between cause and effect has been reversed.

Complex Cause

Alternate Name

<UL>

<LI>Oversimplified Cause</LI>

</UL>

Description

The effect is caused by a number of objects or events, of which the cause is identified is only a part. A variation of this is the feedback loop where the effect is itself a part of the cuase.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The accident was caused by the poor location of the bush. (True, but it wouldn't have occurred had the driver not been drunk and the pedestrian not been jaywalking)</LI>

<LI>The Challenger explosion was caused by the cold weather. (True, however, it would not have occurred had the O-rings been properly constructed.)</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Show that all the causes, and not just the one mentioned, are required to produce the effect.

Genuine but Insignificant Cause

Description

The object or event identified as the cuase of an effect is a genuine cause, but insignificant when compared to the other causes of that event. Note that this fallacy does not apply when all other contributing causes are equally insignificant. Thus, it is not a fallacy to say that you helped cause defeat the Tory government because you voted Reform, for your vote had as much weight as any other vote, and hence is equally a part of the cause.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Smoking is causing air pollution in Edmonton. (True, but the effect of smoking is insignificant compared to the effect of auto exhaust.)</LI>

<LI>By leaving your oven on overnight you are contributing to global warming.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the much more significant cause.

Faulty Analogy

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Weak Analogy</LI>

</UL>

Description

Inductive fallacy associated with analogical reasoning. (Not all analogical reasoning is falty).

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Employees are like nails. Just as nails must be hit in the head in order to make them work; so must employees.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the two objects or events being compared and the property which both are said to possess. Show that the two objects are diferent in a way which will affect whether they both have that property.

Hasty Generalization

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Converse Accident</LI>

<LI>Unrepresentative Sample</LI>

<LI>Biased Sample</LI>

</UL>

Description

Occurs when you form a general rule by examining a small sample which isn't representative of all possible cases.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Fred, the Australian, stole my wallet. Thus, all Australians are thieves.</LI>

<LI>The apples on the top of the box look good. The entire box of apples must be good.</LI>

<LI>To see how Canadians will vote in the next election we polled a hundred people in Calgary. This shows conclusively that the Reform Party will sweep the polls.</LI>

<LI>Because we allow terminally ill patients to use heroin, we should allow everyone to use heroin.</LI>

<LI>Because you allowed Jill, who was hit by a truck, to hand in her assignment late, you should allow the entire class to hand in their assignments late.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the size of the sample and the size of the population, then show that the sample size is too small. Note: a formal proof would require a mathematical calculation. This is the subject of probability theory. For now, you must rely on common sense.

OR Show how the sample is relevantly different from the population as a whole, then show that because the sample is different, the conclusion is probably different.

OR Identify the generalization in question and show how the special case was an exception to the generalization.

Gambler's Fallacy

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>The Monte Carlo Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

An argument of the following form (in reference to something for which each event is independant of successive/preceding events)

x has not occurred recently.

âˆ´ x is likely to happen soon.

Suppressed Evidence

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Missing Premise</LI>

<LI>Card Stacking</LI>

<LI>One-Sided Assessment</LI>

<LI>Slanting</LI>

<LI>One-Sidedness</LI>

</UL>

Description

Leaving a key premise out of the argument while creating the illusion that nothing more is needed to establish the ocnclusion.

Such an argument presents only evidence favoring its conclusion and ignores or downplays evidence against it.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Murder is morally wrong. This being the case, it follows that abortion is morally wrong. (Question begged: How do you know that abortion is a form of murder?)</LI>

<LI>Of course huans and pares evolved from common ancestors. Just look how similar they are. (Question begged: Does the mere fact that humans and apes look similar imply that they evolved from common ancestors?)</LI>

</UL>

Sunk-cost fallacy

Examples

<UL>

<LI>I can't stop now, otherwise what I've invested so far will be lost.<BR>

This may be true, but is irrelevant.</LI>

</UL>

Texas-Sharpshooter Fallacy

Description

The name epidemiologists give to the clustering illusions. Politicians, lawyers and some scientists tend to isolate clusters of diseases from their context, thereby giving the illusions of a causal connection between some environmental factor and the disease.

Argumentum ex silentio

Description

Argument that the silence of a speaker of writer about X proves or suggests that the speaker or writer is ignorant of X.

Slothful Induction

Description

The inductively strong conclusion of an inductive argument is denied despite the evidence to the contrary.

Fallacies of Semantics

[[Description]]

@@ Fallacies where a word or phrase is used unclearly or has multiple meanings.

@@ Ambiguous or Vague statements or words.

Equivocation

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Ambiguous Middle Term</LI>

<LI>Four-Term Fallacy</LI>

<LI>Quaternio Terminorum</LI>

</UL>

Description
