The same word or phrase is used in an argument with two different meanings. Ambiguity generates fallacies when the meaning of an expression shifts during the course of an argument, causing a misleading appearance of validity.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Only man is born free, and no women are men, therefore, no women are born free. (man is used first meaning 'humanity' then meaning 'male')</LI>

<LI>All human fetuses are human. Any human has the right to life. So, all human fetuses have the right to life.</LI>

<LI>All Republicans are democrats. All democrats are liberals. So, all Republicans are liberals.</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>The humanity of the patient's appendix is medially undeniable. So, the appendis has a right to life and should not be surgically removed.</LI>

<LI>The sign said, "fine for parking here", and since it was fine, I parked there.</LI>

<LI>All child-murderers are inhuman, thus, no child murderer is human.</LI>

<LI>A plane is a carpenter's tool, and the Boeing 737 is a plane, hence the Boeing 737 is a carpenter's tool.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the word which is used twice, then show that a definition which is appropriate for one use of the word would not be appropriate for the second use.

Use the counterexample technique:

<UL>

<LI>All dog organs are canine. Any canine must be on a leash. So, all dog organs must be on a leash.</LI>

</UL>

Amphiboly

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Amphibology</LI>

</UL>

Description

Ambiguity at the level of sentence structure (not traceable to any particular word but to how the words are assembled).

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The anthropologists went to a remote area and took photographs of some native women, but they weren't developed. (pronoun ambiguity)</LI>

<LI>One morning I shot an elephant in my pajamas. How he got into my pajamas I'll never know. (modifier ambiguity)</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the ambiguous phrase and show the two possible interpretations.

Scope Fallacy

Description

Limiting words.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>All that glitters is not gold. This rock glitters. So, this rock is not gold.</LI>

</UL>

The first proposition has two meanings

<UL>

<LI>narrow: non-gold.</LI>

<LI>broad: It is not the case that, all that glitters is gold.</LI>

</UL>

Narrow Scope

Description

The word refers only to the word it precedes.

Broad Scope

Description

The word refers to the verb (whole sentence).

Quantifier Shift

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Illicit Quantifier Shift</LI>

</UL>

Description

A fallacy of the form:

âˆ€p Rpq

âˆ´ âˆƒq Rqp

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Every event must have a cause. So, there must be a cause of every event, that is, a first cause which we call "God".</LI>

</UL>

Counter-Examples

<UL>

<LI>Everybody loves someone. Therefore, there is somebody whom everybody loves.</LI>

</UL>

Pronoun Reference

Accent

Description

Emphasis is used to suggest a meaning different from the actual content of the proposition.

(My note) What about a TV commercial, someone advocating a product and smiling as if to say, "This product will make you feel happy, your life more secure".

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The first mate, seeking revent on the captain, wrote in his journal, "The captain was sober today." (Implying the captain is usually drunk)</LI>

<LI>Newspaper headlines</LI>

<LI>contractual fine print</LI>

<LI>commercial "giveaways" and deceptive contest entry forms are frequent sources of fallacies of accent.</LI>

</UL>

Quoting Out of Context

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Abstraction</LI>

</UL>

Description

Two primary forms: Straw Man, and Appeal to Authority.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Have the various fossil candidates for a place in our human ancestry stood the test of time? One by one, variaous fossil man finds have flashed across the front pages of the newspapers and been the subeject of many scientific studies and reports, only to be at least either discredited or just forgotten, replaced by newer finds which also eventually fade away. In 1981 British scientist John Reader commented on this Hollywood character of some of our former alleged ancestors: "Not many (if any) [fossil hominids] have held the stage for long; by now laymen could be forgiven for regarding each new arrival as no less ephemeral than the weather forecast..."</LI>

</UL>

Ignoratio Elenchi

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Missing the Point</LI>

</UL>

Description

The premises of an argument warrant a different conclusion from the one the arguer draws.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Any amount of inflation is bad for the economy. Lastmonth inflation was running at an anual rate of 10 percent. This month the inflation rate is only 7 percent. the economy is on the upswing.</LI>

</UL>

non sequitur

Description

A conclusion that does not follow from the given premises.

Fallacies of Explanations

Description

An explanation is a form of reasoning which attempts to answer the question "why?" For example, it is with an explanation that we answer the questions such as, "Why is the sky blue?"

Subverted Support

Description

An explanation is intended to explain why some phenomenon happens. The explanation is fallacious if the phenomenon does not actually happen or if there is no evidence that it does happen.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The reason why most bachelors are timid is that their mothers were domineering.</LI>

<LI>John went to the store because he wnted to see Maria.</LI>

<LI>The reason why most people oppose the strike is that they are afraid of losing their jobs.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the phenomenon which is being explained. Show that there is no reason to believe that the phenomenon has actually occurred.

Non-support

Description

An explanation is intended to explain why some phenomenon happens. In this case, there is evidence that the phenomenon occurred, but it is trumped up, biased or ad hoc evidence.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>The reason why most bachelors are timid is that their mothers were domineering.</LI>

<LI>The reason why I get four or better on my evaluations is that my students love me.</LI>

<LI>The reason why Alberta has the lowest tuition in Canada is that tuition hikes have lagged behind other provinces.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the phenomenon which is being explained. Show that the evidence advanced to support the existence of the phenomenon was manipulated in some way.

Limited Scope

Description

The theory doesn't explain anything other than the phenomenon it explains.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>There was hostility toward hippies in the 1960s because of their parents' resentment toward children.</LI>

<LI>People get schizophrenia because different parts of their brains split apart.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Identify the theory and phenomenon it explains. Show that the theory does not explain anything else. Argue that theories which explain only the phenomenon are likely to be incomplete, at best.

Limited Depth

Description

Theories explain phenomena by appealing to some underlying cause or phenomena. Theories which do not appeal to an underlying cause, and instead simply appeal to membership in a category, commit the fallacy of limited depth.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>My cat likes tuna because she's a cat.</LI>

<LI>Ronald Reagan was militaristic because he was American.</LI>

<LI>You're just saying that because you belong to the union.</LI>

</UL>

Exposition

Theories of this sort attempt to explain a phenomenon by showing that it is part of a category of similar phenomenon. Accept this, then press for an explanation of the wider category of phenomenon. Argue that a theory refers to a cause, not a classification.

Anecdotal Evidence

Description

Using an anecdote as proof.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>"There's abundant proof that god exists and is still performing miracles today. Just last week I read about a girl who was dying of cancer. Her whold family went to church and prayed for her, and she was cured."</LI>

<LI>Urban Legends</LI>

</UL>

Ad Hoc

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Regressive Fallacy</LI>

<LI>The Regression Fallacy</LI>

</UL>

Description

The Ad Hoc fallacy is to give an after-the-fact explanation which doesn't apply to other situations. Often it will be disguised to resemble an argument.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Assuming god treats everyone equally, then the following is an Ad Hoc explanation:

<UL>

<LI>"I was healed from cancer."</LI>

<LI>"Praise the lord, then. He is your healer."</LI>

<LI>"So, will he heal others who have cancer?"</LI>

<LI>"Er... The ways of god are mysterious."</LI>

</UL>

</UL>

ORR Analysis

ORR (Object Role Requirements)

These fallacies are arranged in a table of three main collumns: Object, Role and Requirements. The Object column enumerates the kinds of objects in an argument. The Role column enumerates the possible roles for each of those objects. The Requirements column list all requirements for each Object-Role Pair. A requirement is written as a 'shall ...' statement. A fourth collum listing related traditional fallacies may also appear in the table. (The ORR table may also be arranged as a hierarchy of three levels.) The ORR system works by first identifying an object, follwed by identifying its role in the argument then listing requirements for that particular object-role. If an object does not fulfill the listed requirements, then the entire argument is fallacious.

The ORR system enumerates three objects in arguments, the proposition, the proposition set and the inference. Below is the hierarchial list of the roles of these two objects.

Proposition:

Premise

Every Premise

...of Evidence

...of Definition

Conclusion

Proposition Set:

The Complete Set of Premises

Inference:

Every Inference

Deduction

Induction

infer attributes

...by composition/division

...by categorization

...by analogy

infer cause/effect relation

infer statistical prediction

Notes

<UL>

<LI>In the following hierarchy, requirements are preceded by 'Req:'</LI>

<LI>In ORR, the term fundamental may be thought of as meaning not circular. Fundamental implies that some reasoning must occur to move from a premise to a conclusion.</LI>

</UL>

Argumentation Theory

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Disputes</LI>

<LI>Two-Sided Arguments</LI>

</UL>

Description

This section is more concerned with live face-to-face argumentation.

Rules of Argumentation

<UL>

<LI>Freedom rule. Parties must not prevent each other from advancing standpoints or from casting doubt on standpoints.</LI>

<LI>Burden of proof rule. A party that advances a standppoint is obliged to defend it if asked by the other party to do so.</LI>

<LI>Standpoint rule. A Party's attack on a standpoint must relate to the standpoint that has indeed been advanced by the other party.</LI>

<LI>Relevance rule. A party may defend a standpoint only by advancing argumentation relating to that standpoint.</LI>

<LI>Unexpressed premise rule. A party may not disown a premise that has been left implicit by that party, or falsely present something as a premise that has been left unexpressed by the other party.</LI>

<LI>Starting point rule. A party may not falsely present a premise as an accepted starting poin nor deny a premise representing an accepted starting point.</LI>

<LI>Argument scheme rule. A party may not regard a standpoint as conclusively defended if the defense does not take place by means of an appropriate argumentation scheme that is correctly applied.</LI>

<LI>Validity rule. A party may only use arguments in its argumentation that are logically valid or capable of being validated by making explicit one or more unexpressed premises.</LI>

<LI>Closure rule. A failed defense of a standpoint must result in the party that put forward the standpoint retracing it and conclusive defense of the standpoint must result in the other party retracing its doubt about the standpoint.</LI>

<LI>Usage rule. A party must not use formulations that are insufficiently clear or confusingly ambiguous and party must interpret the other party's formulations as carefully and accurately as possible.</LI>

</UL>

Emergence

Context

Uses of Language

Overview

This is a very broad set of categories describing the uses of language. Most uses of language are a complex blend of two or more of these.

Cognative (Informative)

Properties

Used to communicate information (and misinformation).

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Affirmation or denial of propositions, presentation of arguments.</LI>

</UL>

Emotive (Expressive)

Properties

Language used to vent or arouse feelings.

Most statements with emotive meaning also contain cognative elements. Since logic is concerned chiefly with cognitive meaning, it's important that we be able to distinguish and disengage the cognitive meaning from the emotive.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Poetry, anger, expression of joy.</LI>

</UL>

Value Claim

Description

Many statements with emotive meaning contain {{I: value claims }}. A value claim is a judgement such as good, bad, right, wrong, better, worse, more important or less important.

Value claims are often the most importantpart of the cognitive meaning of emotive statements. It is often useful to disengage the value claims of emotively charged statements from the emotive meaning and treat these claims as separate statements.

Directive (Imperative)

Properties

Language functioning to cause or prevent overt action.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Commands & requests</LI>

</UL>

Sources

Types of Controversy

Overview

This section outlines the various causes of disputes. Disputes may arise among any one of the uses of language.

Conative

Disputes of Fact (Belief)

Description

Agree or disagree about whether something has in fact taken place or wheather something is true. Most of logic is concerned with this sort of dispute.

Disputes of Definition (Verbal)

Description

A verbal dispute is where two or more parties argue about a subject, but talk past eachother because they don't realize that they actually don't agree upon the definition of a word.

Ambiguity

Description

The term at the root of the dispute has more than one DISTINCT meaning. Each party is arguing with a different meaning in mind.

Vagueness

Description

The term at the root of the dispute has many shades of meaning. Each party is arguing from a different point of view.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Jane: The baby rhino is small.</LI>

<LI>John: 200 lbs is not small.</LI>

</UL>

Emotive

Disputes of Value (Attitude)

Description

Opinion of approval or disapproval toward an event.

Directive

Disputes of Policy

Description

Disagreement about what should be done or how something should be done.

Conditions

Sources of Controversy

Conditions for Argumentation

Description

People argure when the following conditions are met:

Conditions

<UL>

<LI>Some disagreement exists between parties.</LI>

<LI>All parties consider the controversy non-trivial.</LI>

<LI>The assent of the other party is desired.</LI>

<LI>Assent is desired only if it is freely given.</LI>

<LI>No easier means to resolve the disagreement (e.g. Cannot use emprical methods; Cannot consult a universally recognized authority; Cannot deduce the resolution from what's already known)</LI>

</UL>

Issues and Resolutions

Resolution

Definition

<OL>

<LI>A statement capturing the substance of the controversy.</LI>

<LI>If we imagine an answer to the question posed by the controversy, that answer is the resolution.</LI>

</OL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>If the resolution can only be stated in multiple sentences or a single very complex sentence, it may be a sign that the participants are not engaging each other. They may each be addressing a different aspects.</LI>

</UL>

Of Fact (Belief)

Of Value (Attitude)

Of Policy

Of Definition (Verbal)

Issues

Definition

<OL>

<LI>Issues are the questions that are inherent in a controversy and vital to the success of the resolution.</LI>

<LI>Issues are the questions that are asked by a resolution in order to prove it.</LI>

</OL>

Resolution

<UL>

<LI>Interfaith marriages generally fail.</LI>

</UL>

Issues

<UL>

<LI>What counts as an interfaith marriage?</LI>

<LI>What do we mean by succeed?</LI>

<LI>How do we know if it succeeds?</LI>

<LI>etc.</LI>

</UL>

Claims

Description

The proposed intermediary or sub-resolution for each issue.

Topoi

Definition

<OL>

<LI>Stock issues.</LI>

<LI>Shortcuts to locating issues of a controversey</LI>

<LI>Related to the kind of controversy/resolution</LI>

</OL>

For resolutions of Fact (Belief)

<UL>

<LI>What is the criterion for assessing the truth?</LI>

<LI>Has the criterion been satisfied?</LI>

</UL>

For resolutions of Value (Attitude)

<UL>

<LI>Is the value truly good or bad as alleged?</LI>

<LI>Which among competing values should be preferred?</LI>

<LI>Has the value been properly applied to the specific situation?</LI>

</UL>

For resolutions of Policy

<UL>

<LI>Is there a problem?</LI>

<LI>Where is credit or blame due?</LI>

<LI>Will the proposal solve the problem?</LI>

<LI>On balance, will the proposal be better?</LI>

</UL>

For resolutions of Definition (Verbal)

<UL>

<LI>Is the interpretation relevant?</LI>

<LI>Is it fair?</LI>

<LI>How should we choose among competing interpretations?</LI>

</UL>

Stasis

Definition

The focal point of a dispute.

Notes

Stasis is determined by the response to the original assertion.

Stasis in place

Definition

Concerns whether the discussion is occurring in the proper forum.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>

Person A: You stole my car.

Person B: Hey, don't accuse me of theft out here on the street! Theft is a criminal offense. If you've got a case, prosecute! I'll see you in court.

</LI>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>stasis of place is preemptive. It does not take part in the progressive nature of the other three.</LI>

</UL>

Stasis in conjecture

Definitions

Concerns whether a fact is true.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>

Person A: You stole my car.

Person B: No, I never even had posession of it.

</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Stasis of definition concedes stasis of place.</LI>

</UL>

Stasis in definition

Definition

Concerns what a fact should be called.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>

Person A: You stole my car.

Person B: No, I only borrowed it.

</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Stasis of definition concedes stasis of place and conjecture.</LI>

</UL>

Stasis in quality

[[Definition]]

@@ Concerns whether the act is justified.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@

{{PRE:

Person A: You stole my car.

Person B: Yes, but it's a good thing I did because I used it to take to the hospital someone who had fallen on your sidewalk when you hadn't shoveled the snow and ice off, and you would've been liable for it if I hadn't.

}}

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ Stasis of quality concedes stasis of place, conjecture and definition.

Presumption & Burden of Proof

Presumption

[[Definition]]:ordered

@@ What we assume to be the case, unless and until shown otherwise.

@@ A description of the state of affairs before argumentation begins.

@@ Identifies the position that would prevail in the absence of controversy.

@@ A default condition.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@

{{PRE:

A: You stole my car.

B: No, I didn't.

A made the charge, so A has the responsibility to prove it.

}}

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ The party who does not have the presumption, must initiate the dispute.

Natural Presumptions

[[Definiton]]

@@ Those presumptions that are just out there in the world.

[[Examples]]

@@ There is naturally a presumption against restrictions on freedom, because people are by nature free beeings. And so, if we're going to restrict freedom, it's got to be justified.

Artificial Presumptions

[[Definition]]

@@ Presumptions stipulated by convention.

[[Examples]]

@@ The presumption that a person is innocent until proven guilty.

Burden of Proof

[[Definition]]:ordered

@@ The opposite of presumption.

@@ The ultimate responsibility to support one's position on the resolution.

[[Notes]]

@@ The party that lacks presumption is the side that has burden of proof.

@@ Burden of proof does not shift back and forth. One party of a controversy always has the responsibility at the end of the controversy to establish that his or her position prevails. The other party is the one that enjoys presumption.

Who has presumption

[[Overview]]:unordered

@@ There's great strategic advantage in holding presumption.

@@ It is possible to either jockey for presumption or stipulate presumption.

Burden of Rejoinder

[[Definition]]

@@ The burden of going forward with the argument.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@

{{PRE:

A: The federal government, rather than the states, ought to regulate the machinery of elections. Doing so will avoid the problems of the 2000 election season.

B: Why should it be done?

or

B: Well, it shouldn't be done.

In either case, B is not advancing the argument and thus not meeting the burden of rejoinder.

}}

[[Notes]]:unordered

@@ Burden of rejoinder does shift back and forth unlike burden of proof.

Proposition

Proposition

Definition

@@ See {{see("def.proposition"):definition of proposition}}

@@ See definition of Logic.

Analysis

See Also

<UL>

<LI>definition of {{see( "def.analyze" ):Analyze}}</LI>

</UL>

Structure

Description

The most common way to analize a proposition is by its structure structure. More detailed analyses of propositions are possible with the study of Deduction.

All propositions can be classified by structure. We will consider these classifications here. Every proposition can be classified into exactly one of these categories.

Atomic Proposition

{{bookmark( "def.atomic proposition" )}}

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Simple Proposition</LI>

</UL>

Definition

{{MAIN:

@@ A non-negated proposition which cannot be broken down into two or more composite propositions.

}}

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ A cat is a mammal.

@@ All men are mortal.

@@ x=y

@@ Earth is the third planet from the sun.

}}

Negated Proposition

{{bookmark( "def.negated proposition" )}}

Description

{{MAIN:

@@ A proposition which denies a claim.

}}

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ {{TERM:It is not the case that}}, the sky is blue.

@@ {{TERM:It is not the case that}}, all men are mortal.

}}

Compound Proposition

{{bookmark( "def.compound proposition" )}}

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Molecular Proposition

[[Definition]]

{{MAIN:

@@ A proposition composed of two or more simpler propositions joined together by connecting words such as {{TERM:and}}, {{TERM:or}} and {{TERM:if...then...}}. Most connecting words have one of these three meanings or can be rewritten in terms of them. A more detailed study of compound propositions is presented in Deduction.

}}

[[Examples]]:unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ The cat is fat {{TERM:and}} the dog is brown.

@@ {{TERM:If}} it rains, {{TERM:then}} the ground will be wet.

@@ {{TERM:Either}} you're with us {{TERM:or}} you're against us.

}}

Conjunction ('...and...')

[[Description]]

{{MAIN:

@@ Two or more propositions joined by 'and'. A conjunctive proposition asserts that each component proposition is true by itself.

}}

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ The sky is blue {{TERM:and}} the trees are green.

@@ All men and dogs are mammals.{{BR}}

Is the same as: All men are mammals {{TERM:and}} all dogs are mammals.

@@ Tom is a happy, but Mary is not.{{BR}}

Is the same as: Tom is happy {{TERM:and}} it is not the case that Mary is happy.

}}

Disjunction ('...or...')

[[Description]]

{{MAIN:

@@ Two or more propositions joined by 'or'. A disjunctive proposition asserts that at least one of the component propositions is true.

}}

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ a=b {{TERM:or}}, {{TERM:it's not the case that}} a=b.

}}

Conditions ('if...then...')

[[Description]]

@@ Two propositions joined by 'if...then...'. A conditional proposition asserts that if the antecedent (first proposition) is true, then the truth of the consequence (second proposition) is assured. Conditional propositions come in three forms.

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ {{TERM:If}} it's raining {{TERM:then}} the ground is wet.

}}

Sufficient Conditions

{{bookmark( "def.sufficient condition" )}}

[[Form]]: unordered

@@ A is sufficient for B.

[[Semantics]]: unordered

@@ {{TERM:If}} A {{TERM:then}} B.

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition stating a sufficient condition is just a different way of stating an 'if...then...'.

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Being a cat is a {{TERM:sufficient condition}} for being a mammal.{{BR}}

In other words, {{TERM:if}} you're a cat {{TERM:then}} you're a mammal.

@@ Rain is {{TERM:sufficient}} for asserting that the ground is wet.{{BR}}

In other words, {{TERM:if}} it's raining {{TERM:then}} the ground is wet.

}}

Necessary Conditions

{{bookmark( "def.necessary condition" )}}

[[Form]]: unordered

@@ A is necessary for B.

[[Semantics]]: unordered

@@ {{TERM:If not}} A {{TERM:then not}} B.

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition stating a necessary condition asserts that the consequent (B) cannot be the case without the antecedent (A).

[[Examples]]: unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Being a mammal is {{TERM:necessary}} for being a cat.{{BR}}

In other words, {{TERM:if}} you're {{TERM:not}} a mammal, you {{TERM:can't be}} a cat.

@@ The ground being wet is a {{TERM:necessary condition}} for asserting that it's raining.{{BR}}

In other words, {{TERM:if}} the ground is {{TERM:not}} wet, it {{TERM:cannot be}} raining.

}}

Necessary and Sufficient Conditions

{{bookmark( "def.necessary-and-sufficient-condition" )}}

[[Form]]: unordered

@@ A is necessary and sufficient for B.

[[Semantics]]: unordered

@@ {{TERM:If}} A {{TERM:then}} B, {{TERM:and if}} B {{TERM:then}} A.

@@ A {{TERM:if and only if}} B.

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition stating a necessary and sufficient condition is just a different way of stating that if either is true then so is the other; if one is false, then so is the other.

Evaluation

[[Description]]

@@ In this section we study the ways in which logicians evaluate propositions.

[[See Also]]: unordered

@@ definition of {{see( "def.evaluate" ):evaluate}}

Truth Value

{{bookmark( "def.truth value" )}}

[[Definition]]

@@ Part of the definition of a proposition is that it is either true or false. It's {{I:{{B:truth value}}}} is it's evaluation of 'true' or 'false'.

Classification

[[Description]]

@@ Once a proposition, or all propositions in a set have been assigned truth values, it is possible to assign an additional categorical label. This label is boradly called {{TERM:consistency}}.

Logical

Inconsistent

{{bookmark( "def.inconsistent" )}}

[[Alternate Names]]

@@ Falsity

@@ Unsatisfiable

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition that cannot be true.

@@ A set of propositions which cannot be true simultaneously.

[[Examples]]:unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Mars is a planet {{TERM:and}} mars is a star.

@@ Mars is a planet. Mars is a star.

@@ The sun is shining {{TERM:and}} it is night.

}}

Contradiction

{{bookmark( "def.contradiction" )}}

[[Definition]]

@@ A contradiction is any compound proposition of the form: P and not-P.

[[Description]]

@@ A contradiction is a special case of inconsistent propositions because such propositions are inconsistent by form. It is not necessary to understand the meanings of the two component propositions. It is possible to make the sweeping statement that all propositions which have this form are false.

[[Examples]]:unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Tom is tall {{TERM:AND}} Tom is not tall.

}}

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ This first example is false because. Recall the semantics of 'and' as the connective word of a conjunctive proposition. 'and' asserts that both component propositions are true. In this case, if one is true then the other is false. Therefore, the entire proposition is false.

Consistent

{{bookmark( "def.consistent" )}}

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Truth

@@ Satisfiable

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which is true in at least one case. A set of propositions which can be true simultaneously.

Tautology

{{bookmark( "def.tautology" )}}

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Truth

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which cannot be false (true in all cases).

[[Examples]]:unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Either Mars is a planet {{TERM:or}} mars is not a planet.

}}

Contingency

{{bookmark( "def.contingency" )}}

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which is true under some conditions and false under others.

[[Examples]]:unordered

{{DEMO:

@@ Today there is rain.

}}

Semantic

[[Description]]

@@ Propositions may be classified according to what they express.

Fact

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition which asserts.

Definition

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition which equates a word or short phrase to a longer word or short phrase. It states that the two are interchangeable without impacting the meaning (or truth value) of the proposition that contains them.

Definitions

[[Overview]]

@@ Definitions are a particularly well-understood form of proposition. This section discusses what a definition is, the kinds of definitions and techniques for forming good definitions.

The Definition of

[[Definition]]

@@ A definition is always a definition of a symbol by one or more other symbols. (never of/by things or concepts - such as a chair, but of symbols such as 'chair').

Analysis

Structural Components

definiendum

[[Definition]]

@@ The Symbol being defined.

definiens

[[Definition]]

@@ The symbol or group of symbols being used to explain the meaning of the definiendum.

Scope

[[Overview]]

@@ A term used to describe the set of objects or concepts to which a definition applies.

Denotation (Extent/Extention)

[[Definition]]

@@ The collection of objects to which a general term correctly applies constitutes the extension of that term.

Connotation (Intent/Intension)

[[Definition]]

@@ The set of attributes shared by all and only those objects to which a general term refers is called the intension of that term.

Evaluation

Classification

By Purpose

Ambiguity Reduction

[[Properties]]

@@ These definitions are stated for purposes of eliminating ambiguity in text.

Stipulative

[[Properties]]

@@ Defining a new word or a new meaning to an existing word intended to extend only the context in which the defining takes place. A stipulative definition is neither true nor false. A stipulative is a directive use of language (rather than informative).

Lexical

[[Properties]]

@@ Giving the dictionary definition of a given word. No new word is defined. No new definition is created. A Lexical definition is either true or false. A lexical definition is always used in the informative use of language (rather than directive).

Precising Definitions (vagueness reducing)

[[Properties]]

@@ These definitions are stated in order to reduce {{I:vagueness}}.

Theoretical Definitions

[[Properties]]

@@ Dispute about a definition (usually among scientists, politicians or philosophers). Ambiguity and/or vagueness are usually not at steak. They are seeking comprehensive understanding.

[[Examples]]:unordered

@@ Battle among physicists over the definition of "heat", which continued for generations.

Persuasive

[[Properties]]

@@ Definitions formulated and used persuasively, to resolve disputes by influencing the attitudes, or stirring the emotions, of the target audience.

By Form

Denotational (Extensional)

[[Description]]

@@ Identify the collection of objects to which the general term being defined applies.

Enumerative

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Definition by Example

[[Description]]

@@ Define a term by providing examples of objects denoted by it.

Ostensive

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Demonstrative Definitions

[[Description]]

@@ An ostensive definition refers to the examples by means of pointing, or by some other gesture.

quasi-ostensive

[[Description]]

@@ Pointing to an object (example) accompanied by some words.

[[Example]]: unordered

@@ The word 'desk' means this (point to a desk) article of furniture.

Recursive-Inductive

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Definition by Subclass

[[Description]]

@@ Assigns a meaning to a term by naming subclasses of the class denoted by the term.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ 'Tree' means and oak, pine, elm, spruce, maple and the like.

Connotational (Intensional)

[[Description]]

@@ Describe the attributes of such objects.

Subjective

[[Description]]

@@ The set of all attriubtes that the speaker believes to be possessed by objects denoted by that word.

Objective

[[Description]]

@@ The total set of characteristics shared by all the objects in the term's extension.

Contextual

[[Description]]

Conventional

[[Description]]

@@ The subset of objective attributes which are commonly agreed to be the definition of an object.

Synonymous Definition

[[Description]]

@@ Define a word using another word whose meaning is already understood, that has the same meaning as the word being defined.

Operational Definition

[[Description]]

@@ A definition that states that the term is correctly applied to a given case if and only if the performance of specified operations in that case yields a specified result.

Definition by genus and difference

[[Description]]

@@ Genus is the segmenting of groups into categories (classes). Difference is what distinguishes it from the rest of the objects in a particular genus.

Requirements

A definition shall state only the essential attributes of the species.

A definition shall not be circular.

A definition shall be neither too broad nor too narrow

[[Description]]

@@ A definition delimits a set of concepts or objects. A definition is too broad if the definition expresses a set larger than that set actually desired (includes more things). Similarly, a definition is too narrow if it excludes things which are actually in the set. Thus, by these definitions of broad and narrow, it is possible for a definition to be both too broad and too narrow.

A definition shall not be expressed in ambiguous, obscure, or figurative language. If the defined word is vague, the definition shall be only as vague as the defined word.

A definition shall not be negative where it can be affirmative.

A definition shall match, as far as possible, the emotional tone of the term defined.

Philosophical Issues

Truth

Where is truth?

When we speek of truth we implicitly speek of language. For there is no truth/false in the universe. The concept of truth only comes into play when we talk about the universe. So, a fact of the universe is not true or false, it's just the case. But the fact of a sentence is either true or false depending upon weather it accurately mirrors a fact of the universe.

Sentence vs Proposition

A sentence cannot always simply be said to be true or false. But a proposition can. The sentence, "I am an American." Would be true if said by Kennedy but false if said by Khrushchev. Thus, this sentence is not a proposition because the truth is inexact. However, "I Kennedy/Khrushchev, am an American." are clearly propositions since they have clear truth-values. We may say of the first example that it is not a proposition because it may be used to say many different things (Ambiguous? - my note) conversely, different senteces can be used to say the same thing. (E.g. "It's raining." or "Es regnet.").

A proposition makes an object out of the notion of what's said or expressed by the utterance of a certain sort of sentence, namely, one in the indicative mood which makes sense and doesn't fail in its references.

Theories

Correspondence Theory

Truth is a relational concept, like 'ungle', consisting in a relation of correspondence to a fact. (One becomes an ungle by having a niece or nephew.) A thought or proposition is true in those cases, and only those cases, where there is a corresponding fact of the matter. (A man is an uncle in those and only those cases where there is a matching nephew or niece.)

The Core

Ontonogy: Implications for existence

Epistemology: Consequences for knowledge

Facts are independent of our knowledge of them.

Ontological

The study (theoretical/conceptual rather than scientific) of what sorts of things exist.

eg.

Theories to account for human action and perception (hierarchy)

Dualist (mind and body)

Monistic (only mind or body exists)

Physicalist (Deny a separate mind. Theory: complex operations of physical matter.)

Idealist (Deny existence of matter. Theory: experience is simply the experiences of minds.)

Correspondence theorist claims there must be more than this. In addition to individual minds and/or bodies, there must be facts about those minds and/or bodies. The minds and bodies just are -- in addition, there must be facts about them. It is the existence of facts which makes true propositions true. This is a rrealist ontological claim. It is also epistemologically realist.

Epistemological

Consequences for knowledge

Epistemological realism consists in its commitment to what is known as the Law of Bivalence. By making truth a matter of the existence of a certain sort of object, the theory commits itself to the possibility that propositions may be true or false, but which they are we have no way of determining.

Law of Bivalence

Every proposition either has a corresponding fact in which case it's true; or does not in which case it's false.

So truth is dependent upon the existence of a corresponding object.

E.g.

'Oswald killed Kennedy.' Is a proposition, we may, however, not know it's truth. We don't know if there is a corresponding fact. Such a proposition is called 'verification-transcendent'.

Problems

Wittgenstein

Elementary propositions get their meaning by association with-by corresponding to-particular states of affairs. The visible (or audible) part of a proposition is a sentence, a sequence of signs. These signs become symbols by an arbitrary act of correlating them with objects. Facts about those symbols then come conventionally to picture certain states of affairs about the corresponding objets. Thus at the heart of Wittgenstein's correspondence theory of truth is a picture theory of meaning. Elementary propositions are facts about names, and thereby picture (or mean) atomic states of affairs, that is, certain combinations of objects. In gereral, propositions (via the connection at the base level of elementary propositions and atomic facts) picture putative facts, or states of affairs.

Analytic/Synthetic

Analytic Statement

[[Definition]]

@@ An analytic statement is one that is a tautology.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All bachelors are unmarried.

@@ 2 = 2

@@ 1 > 0

@@ All frogs are frogs.

@@ If everything is green, then this is green.

Synthetic Statement

[[Definition]]

@@ A synthetic statement is one that's contingent.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ Daniel is a bachelor.

How can we know something is true?

a priori/posteriori knowledge

[[Description]]

@@ Philosophers traditionally distinguish two kinds of knowledge.

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ Most of our knowledge is {{I:a posteriori}}. Logical and mathematical knowledge is generally {{I:a priori}}.

A Posteriori

[[Definition]]

@@ A posteriori (empirical) knowledge is knowledge based upon sense experience.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ Some bachelors are happy.

A Priori

[[Definition]]

@@ A priori (rational) knowledge is knowledge not base on sense experience.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All bachelors are unmarried.

Analytic/Synthetic vs. a priori/a posteriori

[[Description]]

@@ It may appear that a priori propositions can only be analytic and that a posteriori propositions can only be synthetic, but this is not the case.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ "PI is a little over 3."{{BR}}

Analytic{{BR}}

It can be known a posteriori through measurement.{{BR}}

It can be known a priori through calculation.

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ These examples seem to suggest that perhaps any analytic statement that is known a posteriori also could be known a priori. So, the biggest question is, "Do we have any purely synthetic a priori knowledge?"

Inference

Description

The bulk of active study in logic is concerned with the inferential claim. How do we know that a deductive argument is valid or that an inductive argument is strong?

See Also

<UL>

<LI>Definition of {{see( "def.classical-logic" ):Classical Logic}}.</LI>

</UL>

Deduction

{{bookmark( "section.deduction" )}}

Description

An argument in which it is impossible for the conclusion to be false while the premises are all true.

In this section we'll cover formal deductive logics and their related theories of inference.

Proof

{{bookmark( "def.proof" )}}

[[Definition]]

@@ A noncircular, nonambiguous, valid deductive argument with clearly true premises.

Classification

[[Description]]

@@ Proofs may be cateogrized by their purpose.

Proof of Consequence

{{bookmark( "def.proof-of-consequence" )}}

[[Definition]]

@@ A proof of consequence is a proof that demonstrates that some conconclusion Î¨ follows necessarilly (validly) from some set of premises Î“. This can be notated as:

{{OFFSET:

Î“ âŠ¦ Î¨

}}

[[See Also]]: unordered

@@ Definition of {{see( "def.theorem" ): theorem }}.

Proof of Nonconsequence

{{bookmark( "def.proof-of-nonconsequence" )}}

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Refutation Proofs

@@ Proofs of Refutation

@@ (Proof of) Counter Example

[[Description]]

@@ A proof constructed to demonstrate that some conclusion Î¨ does not follow from some set of Premises Î“.

{{OFFSET:

Î“ âŠ¬ Î¨

}}

[[Elements]]: ordered

@@ Affirmation of all the argument's premises.

@@ A denial of the argument's conclusion.

@@ An explanation (or example) of how this can be.

[[Technique]]: unordered

@@ Prove that it is possible for the conclusion to be false while all the premises are true.

Techniques

Leibniz' Axioms (Proof Method)

{{bookmark( "section.leibniz-laws" )}}

[[Description]]

@@ Leibniz developed a logic based upon four axioms which he then used to prove all the valid inferences in Term Logic.

[[Axioms]]: ordered

@@ Everything is identical to itself{{BR}}

a=a

@@ Law of non-contradiction{{BR}}

Â¬(P âˆ§ Â¬P)

@@ Law of excluded middle{{BR}}

P âˆ¨ Â¬P

@@ Law of substitution{{BR}}

a=b, b=c. So, a=c

Reductio ad absurdum

{{bookmark("def.reductio")}}

[[Description]]

@@ Leibniz used his law of non-contradiction and law of excluded middle to create the reductio ad absurdum (indirect proof). A method of proof where we start with a set of consistent premises, then assert the negation of what we want to prove. If a contradiction is consequently infered, then the negated conclusion must also be false. Hence, the non-negated form of the conclusion must be true.

@@ It is most common to use reducio ad absurdum to introduce an entirely new proposition into a proof. This is done by introducing a hypothetical argument with a hypothesis (negated form of the proposition). Then the contradiction must be proved to be able to introduce the desired proposition. A hypothetical argument is usually introduced by phrases like 'let's suppose' and 'if we suppose'.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ Who stole the cookies?

{{PRE:

If someone can reach the cookies, then he is tall.

If someone stole the cookies, then he can reach the cookies.

John is not tall.

Suppose that, John stole the cookies.

John can reach the cookies. (from second premise and supposition)

John is tall. (from first premise and previous proposition)

John is tall AND John is not tall. (from third premise and previous proposition)

<B>âˆ´</B> John did not steal the cookies.

}}

Proof by cases

[[Description]]

@@ Given a premise of alternatives ( P v Q v ... ) If we can prove one case at a time (using sub proofs) that each alternative implies some R (that is, prove that (P â†’ R), and that (Q â†’ R), etc.), then we can dismiss the premise of alternatives and infer R.

Two-Column Proofs

{{bookmark( "two-column-proof" )}}

[[Description]]

@@ A two-column proof is a proof which follows a standard form designed to make the proof easier to follow.

Structure

[[Description]]

@@ A two-column proof is a sequence of numbered steps, one-per-line, each with the following form:

{{PRE:

<step> <proposition> <reason>

}}

@@ <step> is the step number. Steps are numbered starting with 1.

@@ <proposition> is the proposition on that step of the proof.

@@ <reason> is the reasoning behind why you asserted the proposition at this step of the proof. If the proposition is one of the original premises you can write 'given'. If the proposition is a consequence of previous steps, those steps are cited in the reason.

Metatheory

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Metalogic</LI>

</UL>

Description

Just as facts of the phenomenological world are the objects of logics, so are these logics the objects of metalogic. In short metalogic proves things about logic.

Formal Languages

Definition

A formal language is a language which has syntax (structure or form) but is absent of any interpretation. Formal languages are the objects of metatheory.

Lexemes

Definition

The lexemes (or tokens) are the marks or string of marks of a language

Well Formed Formulas

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Formulas</LI>

<LI>wffs</LI>

<LI>Sentences</LI>

</UL>

Definition

A syntactically correct sequence of symbols in a formal language is called a well formed formula.

Model Theory

Definition

Model theory is the theory of interpretations of formal languages.

A Model of a formula of a language is an interpretation of the language for which the formula comes out true.

Interpretation

Definition

An interpretation of a formal langauge is an assignment of meanings to its symbols and/or formulas.

Proof Theory

Definition

Proof theory is the theory of a deductive apparatus for a language.

By specifying a deductive apparatus for a formal language we get a formal system.

Formal System

Definition

A formal system S is a formal language L together with a deductive apparatus.

A deductive apparatus is given by one or both of:

<UL>

<LI>Designating certain formulas of L as axioms of S.</LI>

<LI>Specifying a set of transformation rules (also called rules of inference) that determines which relations between formulas of L are relations of immedicate consequence in S. (i.e. the transformation rules license the derivation of some formulas from others.)</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>The deductive apparatus must be definable without reference to any intended interpretation of the language: otherwise the system is not a formal system.</LI>

<LI>A deductive apparatus can consist of axioms and rules of inference, or of axioms alone, o or of rules of inference alone.</LI>

</UL>

Axiomatic

Description

An axiomatic system of inference is one in which there is one or more formal propositions (called axioms) which are part of the calculus. The calculus also has "inference rules", rules governing how premises and axiom may be inserted into the proof and how to infer new propositions.

Axiomatic systems are not commonly used today because it's difficult to see how to get to the conclusion from a set of premises and the intermediate inferences tend to derive very long and cumbersome propositions. The advantages of the axiomatic calculi are that there tends to be relatively few inference rules and axioms. The greater difficulty in deriving the proofs is what makes them far less desirable than other systems.

Natural Deduction

Description

Natural deduction, so called because it more closely models human thought process than axiomatic calculi, eliminates the axioms and introduces additional inference rules. Typically, the inference theories presented in this outline are of this variety.

Effective Method

Definition

Akin to an algorithm. An effective method is a means by which we may carry out a procedure purely mechanically, it requires no imagination on the part of the user at all.

Set Theory

Set

Cardinality

Definition

The cardinality of a set is the number of members of that set. The cardinality of a set Î© is written |Î©|.

Proper Subset

Definition

A set A is a proper subset of a different set B (written A âŠ‚ B) iff every member of A is also in B but there is at least one member of B not in A.

Decidable Set

Definition

A set is decidable if and only if there is an effective method for telling, for each thing that might be a member of the set, whether or not it really is a member.

1-1 correspondence

Definition

There is a 1-1 correspondence between a set A and a set B iff ther eis a way (which need not be known to anyone) of pairing off the members of A with the members of B so that:

<UL>

<LI>each member of A is paired with exactly one member of B</LI>

<LI>each member of B is paired with exactly one member of A.</LI>

</UL>

So it follows that no member of either set is left unpaired.

Denumerable

Definition

A set is denumerable iff ther is a 1-1 correspondence between it and the set of natural numbers ( 0, 1, 2, 3, ... ).

So, a denumerable set has an infinite cardinality.

Logics

Logicians use the term 'Logic' ambiguously. In the general sense, 'logic' is used to name the study of argumentation. However, 'logic' may also be used as a term to describe a specific coherent system consisting of a specific formal language, interpretation and proof theory.

Classical Logics

Description

Formal logics study patterns of reasoning. In formal deductive logic, a deductive argument is valid if and only if it follows a form already considered valid.

Classical logics exhibit several characteristics:

<UL>

<LI>defines a proposition as a statement which makes a claim.</LI>

<LI>conforms to {{see("section.leibniz-laws"):Leibniz' Laws}}.{{BR}}

Which consequently permits the use of the {{see("def.reductio"):reductio ad absurdum}} proof technique.</LI>

<LI>studies one or both of the logical concepts of the truth-functional operators and the grouping of things.</LI>

</UL>

Notes

<UL>

<LI>Logics which do not conform to the last criterion (which is widely considered trivial) but extend the language of some strictly classical logic, are often categorized as extension (or extended) classical logics. </LI>

<LI>Interestingly, classical logic does not require that the premises be relevant to the conclusion. In most cases the inferential claim takes care of relevance, but there are exceptions which allow a conclusion from premises irrelevant to it.</LI>

</UL>

A-Logics

{{bookmark( "section.term-logic" )}}

Alternate Names

<UL>

<LI>Term Logic</LI>

<LI>Categorical Logic</LI>

<LI>Syllogistic Logic</LI>

</UL>

Description

A-Logics (or Aristotlean logics) are a family of logics, which were used by the Ancient Greeks and come down to us through Aristotle's writings. It's very unlikely that Aristotle himself devised this system of reasoning but probably did contribute to it.

A-Logic studies arguments whose validity depends on 'all', 'no', 'some' and similar notions.

Aristotlean

Description

This is a relatively little-known but quite intriguing interpretation due to an alternate translation (and perhaps a superior translation) of Aristotle's works. See the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (plato.stanford.edu), square of opposition, section 2.2.

Formal Language

Lexical Elements

Quantifier

Defintion

A word which states what portion of a category about which a proposition refers.

Forms

<UL>

<LI>The universal quantifier: "All"</LI>

<LI>The universal quantifier: "No"</LI>

<LI>The particular quantifier: "Some"</LI>

<LI>The particular quantifier: "Not every"</LI>

<LI>The singular quantifier: <empty></LI>

</UL>

Copula

{{bookmark( "def.copula" )}}

Definition

The word that seapartes the subject and prediate terms.

Forms

<UL>

<LI>"is" (or "are")</LI>

</UL>

Term

Description

Terms are elements that are not part of the language of term logic. Rather, they denote objects and cateogries which are in the domain of the argument being presented.

Categorical Term

Description

A categorical term denotes a group of objects.

Forms

It's traditional to signify a categorical term by an upper case letter.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>C, cat</LI>

<LI>R, religious people</LI>

<LI>M, males</LI>

</UL>

Singular Term

Description

A singular term denotes a particular object.

Forms

It's traditional to signify a categorical term by an lower case letter.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>t, Tom</LI>

<LI>m, the man standing on the corner.</LI>

<LI>f, Mary's father</LI>

</UL>

Well-Formed Formulas (WFF's)

Description

Generally, a proposition of Term Logic takes the following syntax:

quantifier subject-term copula predicate-term

This results in eight possible proposition forms which are traditionally given names (A, E, I, O, As and Es).

A: all A is B.

E: no A is B.

I: some A is B.

O: not every A is B.

As: a is b

a is B

Es: a is not b.

a is not B.

Alternate Representations

Lemmon

Description

Lemmon ignores singular form propositions.

Let A,E,I and O represent the four categorical propositions and S, and P represent arbitrary subject and predicate terms.

affirmative negative

universal: A(S,P) E(S,P)

particular: I(S,P) O(S,P)

Algebraic Symbolism

Description

A Boolean algebraic technique is often used to represent the categorical propositions.

0 (zero) is used to represent the empty set. Propositions are witten as equations being equal to or not equal to the empty set. These are written using the equal sign and the not-equal sign. We will use = and != for these respectively.

Categories will be notated by capital letters. A complement (everything NOT in a category) will be noted by placing a bar over the category letter (here we will follow the letter by a single quote). To represent the intersection of two sets (the set of things common to two sets), we place a dot between them. This dot is often omitted.

Using S and P to notate the subject and predicate terms. The four cateogrical forms can then be written as:

A SP' = 0

E SP = 0

I SP != 0

O SP' != 0

Formalization Hints

Description

In common speech, categorical propositions rarely appear in one of the eight standard forms. The following is a set of 'hints' for translating such propositions into a standard form proposition.

Terms Without Nouns

Descriptions

A categorical proposition must have a noun for each the subject term and the predicate term. If one is missing, it should be filled in.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Some roses are red.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some roses are red flowers.</LI>

<LI>All tigers are carnivorous.{{BR}}

Becomes: All tigers are carnivorous animals.</LI>

</UL>

Nonstandard Verbs

Description

The only copulas permissible in the standard form proposition are 'is' and 'is not'.

Sometimes the copula is an alternate form of the verb 'to be'. Othertimes it's a completely different verb.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Some college students will become educated.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some college students are persons who will become educated.</LI>

<LI>Some dogs would rather bark than bite.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some dogs are animals that would rather bark than bite.</LI>

<LI>Some birds fly south during the winter.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some birds are animals that fly south during the winter.</LI>

<LI>All ducks swim.{{BR}}

Becomes: All ducks are animals that swim.</LI>

</UL>

Singular Propositions

Description

These are named persons, places, things or times. They may be translated by means of one of the following phrases:

persons identical to

places identical to

things identical to

cases identical to

times identical to

Examples

<UL>

<LI>George went home.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons identical to George are persons who went home.</LI>

<LI>Sandra did not go shopping.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons identical to Sandra are persons who did not go shopping.</LI>

<LI>I hate gin.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons who are identical to me are persons who hate gin.</LI>

</UL>

Adverbs and Pronouns

Description

Spacial adverbs: where, wherever, anywhere, everywhere or nowhere; may be translated in terms of 'places'.

Temporal adverbs: when, whenever, anytime, always or never; may be translated in terms of 'times'.

Pronouns: who, whoever or anyone; may be translated in terms of 'persons'.

Pronouns: what, whatever or anything; may be translated in terms of 'things'.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>He always wears a suit to work.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times he goes to work are times he wears a suit.</LI>

<LI>He is always clean shaven.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times are times he is clean shaven.</LI>

<LI>She never brings her lunch to school.{{BR}}

Becomes: No times she goes to school are times she brings her lunch.</LI>

<LI>Nowhere on earth are there any unicorns.{{BR}}

Becomes: No places on earth are places there are unicorns.</LI>

<LI>Whoever works hard will succeed.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons who work hard are persons who will succeed.</LI>

<LI>He glitters when he walks.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times he walks are times he glitters.</LI>

<LI>She goes where she chooses.{{BR}}

Becomes: All places she chooses to go are places she goes.</LI>

<LI>She does what she wants.{{BR}}

Becomes: All things she wants to do are things she does.</LI>

</UL>

Unexpressed Quantifiers

Description

Many statements have implied quantifiers.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Emeralds are green gems.{{BR}}

Becomes: All emeralds are green gems.</LI>

<LI>There are lions in the zoo.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some lions are animals in the zoo.</LI>

<LI>A tiger is a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: All tigers are mammals.</LI>

<LI>A fish is not a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: No fish are mammals.</LI>

<LI>A tiger roared.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some tigers are animals that roared.</LI>

<LI>Children are human beings.{{BR}}

Becomes: All children are human beings.</LI>

<LI>Children live next door.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some childern are persons who live next door.</LI>

</UL>

Nonstandard Quantifiers

[[Description]]

@@ Often quantifiers other than the standard form quantifiers are used.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ A few soldiers are heroes.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} soldiers {{TERM:are}} heroes.

@@ Anyone who votes is a citizen.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} voters {{TERM:are}} citizens.

@@ Not everyone who votes is a Democrat.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} voters {{TERM:are not}} Democrats.

@@ Not a single dog is a cat.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} dogs {{TERM:are}} cats.

@@ All newborns are not able to talk.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} newborns {{TERM:are}} people able to talk.

@@ All prisoners are not violent.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} prisoners {{TERM:are not}} violent people.

@@ Few sailors entered the regatta.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} sailors {{TERM:are}} persons who entered the regatta and {{TERM:some}} sailors {{TERM:are not}} persons who entered the regatta.

Conditional Statements

[[Description]]

@@ When the antecedent and consequent of a conditional statement talk about the same thing, the statement can usually be translated into categorical form. Such statements are always translated as universals.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ If it's a mouse, then it's a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} mice {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If it's a turkey, then it's not a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} turkeys {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If an animal has four legs, then it is not a bird.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} four-legged animals {{TERM:are}} birds.

@@ If Los Angeles is in California, then Los Angeles is a large city.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} California cities identical to Los Angeles {{TERM:are}} large cities.

@@ A person will succeed if he or she perceveres.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who percevere {{TERM:are}} persons who will succeed.

@@ Jewelery is expensive if it is made of gold.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} gold jewelery {{TERM:is}} expensive.

@@ If it's not a mammal, then it's not a mouse.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} mice {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If a company is not well managed, then it is not a good investment.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} companies that are good investements {{TERM:are}} well-managed companies.

@@ Tomatoes are edible unless they are spoiled.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} unspoiled tomatoes {{TERM:are}} edible tomatoes.

@@ Unless a boy misbehaves he will be treated decently.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} boys who do not misbehave {{TERM:are}} boys who will be treated decently.

Exclusive Propositions

[[Description]]

@@ Many propositions that involve the words 'only', 'none but', 'none except' and 'no...except' are exclusive propositions. In these cases the predicate is usually phrased first.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ Only elected officials will attend the convention.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who will attent the convention {{TERM:are}} elected officials.

@@ None but the brave deserve the fair.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who deserve the fair {{TERM:are}} brave persons.

@@ No birds except peacocks are proud of their tails.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} birds proud of their tails {{TERM:are}} peacocks.

@@ He owns only blue-chip stocks.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} stocks owned by him {{TERM:are}} blue-chip stocks.

@@ She invited only wealthy socialites.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons invited by her {{TERM:are}} wealthy socialites.

Exceptive Propositions

[[Description]]

@@ Propositions of the form "all except S are P" and "All but S are P". These must be translated as pairs of conjoined categorical propositions.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All except students are invited.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} students {{TERM:are}} invited persons, and {{TERM:all}} nonstudents {{TERM:are}} invited persons.

@@ All but managers must report to the president.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} managers {{TERM:are}} person who must report to the president, and {{TERM:all}} non-managers {{TERM:are}} persons who must report to the president.

"The Only"

[[Description]]

@@ Statements beginning 'the only' are translated differently from those beginning with 'only'. In this case, the terms are not reversed.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ The only animals that live in this canyon are skunks.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} animals that live in this canyon {{TERM:are}} skunks.

@@ Accountants are the only ones who will be hired.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} those who will be hired {{TERM:are}} accountants.

Formal Language

Lexical Elements

Quantifier

Defintion

A word which states what portion of a category about which a proposition refers.

Forms

<UL>

<LI>The universal quantifier: "All"</LI>

<LI>The universal quantifier: "No"</LI>

<LI>The particular quantifier: "Some"</LI>

<LI>The particular quantifier: "Not every"</LI>

<LI>The singular quantifier: <empty></LI>

</UL>

Copula

{{bookmark( "def.copula" )}}

Definition

The word that seapartes the subject and prediate terms.

Forms

<UL>

<LI>"is" (or "are")</LI>

</UL>

Term

Description

Terms are elements that are not part of the language of term logic. Rather, they denote objects and cateogries which are in the domain of the argument being presented.

Categorical Term

Description

A categorical term denotes a group of objects.

Forms

It's traditional to signify a categorical term by an upper case letter.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>C, cat</LI>

<LI>R, religious people</LI>

<LI>M, males</LI>

</UL>

Singular Term

Description

A singular term denotes a particular object.

Forms

It's traditional to signify a categorical term by an lower case letter.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>t, Tom</LI>

<LI>m, the man standing on the corner.</LI>

<LI>f, Mary's father</LI>

</UL>

Well-Formed Formulas (WFF's)

Description

Generally, a proposition of Term Logic takes the following syntax:

quantifier subject-term copula predicate-term

This results in eight possible proposition forms which are traditionally given names (A, E, I, O, As and Es).

A: all A is B.

E: no A is B.

I: some A is B.

O: not every A is B.

As: a is b

a is B

Es: a is not b.

a is not B.

Alternate Representations

Lemmon

Description

Lemmon ignores singular form propositions.

Let A,E,I and O represent the four categorical propositions and S, and P represent arbitrary subject and predicate terms.

affirmative negative

universal: A(S,P) E(S,P)

particular: I(S,P) O(S,P)

Algebraic Symbolism

Description

A Boolean algebraic technique is often used to represent the categorical propositions.

0 (zero) is used to represent the empty set. Propositions are witten as equations being equal to or not equal to the empty set. These are written using the equal sign and the not-equal sign. We will use = and != for these respectively.

Categories will be notated by capital letters. A complement (everything NOT in a category) will be noted by placing a bar over the category letter (here we will follow the letter by a single quote). To represent the intersection of two sets (the set of things common to two sets), we place a dot between them. This dot is often omitted.

Using S and P to notate the subject and predicate terms. The four cateogrical forms can then be written as:

A SP' = 0

E SP = 0

I SP != 0

O SP' != 0

Formalization Hints

Description

In common speech, categorical propositions rarely appear in one of the eight standard forms. The following is a set of 'hints' for translating such propositions into a standard form proposition.

Terms Without Nouns

Descriptions

A categorical proposition must have a noun for each the subject term and the predicate term. If one is missing, it should be filled in.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Some roses are red.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some roses are red flowers.</LI>

<LI>All tigers are carnivorous.{{BR}}

Becomes: All tigers are carnivorous animals.</LI>

</UL>

Nonstandard Verbs

Description

The only copulas permissible in the standard form proposition are 'is' and 'is not'.

Sometimes the copula is an alternate form of the verb 'to be'. Othertimes it's a completely different verb.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Some college students will become educated.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some college students are persons who will become educated.</LI>

<LI>Some dogs would rather bark than bite.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some dogs are animals that would rather bark than bite.</LI>

<LI>Some birds fly south during the winter.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some birds are animals that fly south during the winter.</LI>

<LI>All ducks swim.{{BR}}

Becomes: All ducks are animals that swim.</LI>

</UL>

Singular Propositions

Description

These are named persons, places, things or times. They may be translated by means of one of the following phrases:

persons identical to

places identical to

things identical to

cases identical to

times identical to

Examples

<UL>

<LI>George went home.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons identical to George are persons who went home.</LI>

<LI>Sandra did not go shopping.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons identical to Sandra are persons who did not go shopping.</LI>

<LI>I hate gin.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons who are identical to me are persons who hate gin.</LI>

</UL>

Adverbs and Pronouns

Description

Spacial adverbs: where, wherever, anywhere, everywhere or nowhere; may be translated in terms of 'places'.

Temporal adverbs: when, whenever, anytime, always or never; may be translated in terms of 'times'.

Pronouns: who, whoever or anyone; may be translated in terms of 'persons'.

Pronouns: what, whatever or anything; may be translated in terms of 'things'.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>He always wears a suit to work.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times he goes to work are times he wears a suit.</LI>

<LI>He is always clean shaven.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times are times he is clean shaven.</LI>

<LI>She never brings her lunch to school.{{BR}}

Becomes: No times she goes to school are times she brings her lunch.</LI>

<LI>Nowhere on earth are there any unicorns.{{BR}}

Becomes: No places on earth are places there are unicorns.</LI>

<LI>Whoever works hard will succeed.{{BR}}

Becomes: All persons who work hard are persons who will succeed.</LI>

<LI>He glitters when he walks.{{BR}}

Becomes: All times he walks are times he glitters.</LI>

<LI>She goes where she chooses.{{BR}}

Becomes: All places she chooses to go are places she goes.</LI>

<LI>She does what she wants.{{BR}}

Becomes: All things she wants to do are things she does.</LI>

</UL>

Unexpressed Quantifiers

Description

Many statements have implied quantifiers.

Examples

<UL>

<LI>Emeralds are green gems.{{BR}}

Becomes: All emeralds are green gems.</LI>

<LI>There are lions in the zoo.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some lions are animals in the zoo.</LI>

<LI>A tiger is a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: All tigers are mammals.</LI>

<LI>A fish is not a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: No fish are mammals.</LI>

<LI>A tiger roared.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some tigers are animals that roared.</LI>

<LI>Children are human beings.{{BR}}

Becomes: All children are human beings.</LI>

<LI>Children live next door.{{BR}}

Becomes: Some childern are persons who live next door.</LI>

</UL>

Nonstandard Quantifiers

[[Description]]

@@ Often quantifiers other than the standard form quantifiers are used.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ A few soldiers are heroes.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} soldiers {{TERM:are}} heroes.

@@ Anyone who votes is a citizen.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} voters {{TERM:are}} citizens.

@@ Not everyone who votes is a Democrat.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} voters {{TERM:are not}} Democrats.

@@ Not a single dog is a cat.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} dogs {{TERM:are}} cats.

@@ All newborns are not able to talk.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} newborns {{TERM:are}} people able to talk.

@@ All prisoners are not violent.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} prisoners {{TERM:are not}} violent people.

@@ Few sailors entered the regatta.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:Some}} sailors {{TERM:are}} persons who entered the regatta and {{TERM:some}} sailors {{TERM:are not}} persons who entered the regatta.

Conditional Statements

[[Description]]

@@ When the antecedent and consequent of a conditional statement talk about the same thing, the statement can usually be translated into categorical form. Such statements are always translated as universals.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ If it's a mouse, then it's a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} mice {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If it's a turkey, then it's not a mammal.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} turkeys {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If an animal has four legs, then it is not a bird.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} four-legged animals {{TERM:are}} birds.

@@ If Los Angeles is in California, then Los Angeles is a large city.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} California cities identical to Los Angeles {{TERM:are}} large cities.

@@ A person will succeed if he or she perceveres.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who percevere {{TERM:are}} persons who will succeed.

@@ Jewelery is expensive if it is made of gold.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} gold jewelery {{TERM:is}} expensive.

@@ If it's not a mammal, then it's not a mouse.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} mice {{TERM:are}} mammals.

@@ If a company is not well managed, then it is not a good investment.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} companies that are good investements {{TERM:are}} well-managed companies.

@@ Tomatoes are edible unless they are spoiled.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} unspoiled tomatoes {{TERM:are}} edible tomatoes.

@@ Unless a boy misbehaves he will be treated decently.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} boys who do not misbehave {{TERM:are}} boys who will be treated decently.

Exclusive Propositions

[[Description]]

@@ Many propositions that involve the words 'only', 'none but', 'none except' and 'no...except' are exclusive propositions. In these cases the predicate is usually phrased first.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ Only elected officials will attend the convention.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who will attent the convention {{TERM:are}} elected officials.

@@ None but the brave deserve the fair.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons who deserve the fair {{TERM:are}} brave persons.

@@ No birds except peacocks are proud of their tails.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} birds proud of their tails {{TERM:are}} peacocks.

@@ He owns only blue-chip stocks.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} stocks owned by him {{TERM:are}} blue-chip stocks.

@@ She invited only wealthy socialites.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} persons invited by her {{TERM:are}} wealthy socialites.

Exceptive Propositions

[[Description]]

@@ Propositions of the form "all except S are P" and "All but S are P". These must be translated as pairs of conjoined categorical propositions.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All except students are invited.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} students {{TERM:are}} invited persons, and {{TERM:all}} nonstudents {{TERM:are}} invited persons.

@@ All but managers must report to the president.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:No}} managers {{TERM:are}} person who must report to the president, and {{TERM:all}} non-managers {{TERM:are}} persons who must report to the president.

"The Only"

[[Description]]

@@ Statements beginning 'the only' are translated differently from those beginning with 'only'. In this case, the terms are not reversed.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ The only animals that live in this canyon are skunks.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} animals that live in this canyon {{TERM:are}} skunks.

@@ Accountants are the only ones who will be hired.{{BR}}

Becomes: {{TERM:All}} those who will be hired {{TERM:are}} accountants.

Interpretation Structures

Of Terms

Distribution

[[Description]]

@@ An attribute of a term. Distribution says that the term speeks of <I>every</I> member of the class mentioned by the term. The following are common techniques for finding the distributed terms.

Determination by Form

[[Forms & Distribution]]: unordered

@@ A form propositions - the subject is distributed

@@ E form propositions - the subject & predicate are distributed

@@ I form propositions - nothing is distributed

@@ O form propositions - the predicate is distributed

Determination by Attribute

[[Attributes & Distribution]]: unordered

@@ Universal propositions - the subject is distributed

@@ Negative propositions - the predicate is distributed

Determination by Indicators

[[Indicators & Distribution]]: unordered

@@ the word 'all' - the term that follows immediately after

@@ the negatives, 'no' and 'not' - all terms that follow.

Of Propositions

Quantity

[[Description]]

@@ The number of items in the subject term being talked about.

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ Singular is just a special case of the Particular.

Universal

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which refers to all members of the subject term.

@@ Universal propositions begin with one of the universal quantifiers, 'all' or 'no'.

@@ All A and E propositions are universal propositions; and vice-versa.

Particular

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which refers to at least one member of the subject term.

@@ Particular propositions begin with the particular quantifier, 'some'

@@ All I and O propositions are particular propositions; and vice-versa.

Singular

[[Definition]]

@@ A proposition which refers to an individual.

@@ Particular propositions have no quantifier.

@@ All As and Es propositions are singular propositions; and vice-versa.

Quality

[[Description]]

@@ affirmative or negative

Affirmative

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition which asserts that something is the case.

@@ Affirmative universals begin with the quantifier 'all'. Affirmative particulars and singulars use the copula 'is' (or 'are').

@@ All A, I and As propositions are affirmatives; and vice-versa.

Negative

[[Description]]

@@ A proposition which denies that something is the case.

@@ All negative propositions contain the word 'no' or 'not', and vice-versa.

@@ All E, O and Es propositions are negative; and vice-versa.

Existential Import

[[Description]]

@@ Existential Import is the concept that a categorical proposition entails the assertion that its terms exist.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All horses are mammals.{{BR}}

Existential import says there are two implied propositions: Horses exist, and Mammals exist.{{BR}}

@@ Some unicorns are mammals.{{BR}}

Existential import says there are two implied propositions: Unicorns exist. and Mammals exist.{{BR}}

@@ Some mammals are unicorns.{{BR}}

Existential import says there are two implied propositions: Mammals exist, and Unicorns exist.

[[Notes]]: unordered

@@ Existential import does not mean that the objects do in fact exist, it just {{I:asserts}} that they exist. This assertion may in fact be false.

Interpretations

Traditional Interpretation

[[Description]]

@@ This interpretation is traditionally attributed to Aristotle. The traditional interpretation says that all four categorical proposition forms have Existential Import. This interpretation, however, is problematic. If all terms actually do exist, then we get correct conclusions. However, if a term doesn't refer to something that actually exists, the conclusion is wrong.

[[Examples]]

@@ All pheasants are birds.{{BR}}

implies the existence of pheasants and birds.

@@ No pine trees are maples.{{BR}}

implies the existence of pine trees and maples.

@@ All satyrs are vile creatures.{{BR}}

Implies the existence of satyrs and vile creatures.

Modern Interpretation

[[Alternate Names]]: unordered

@@ Boolean Interpretation

[[Description]]

@@ This is the interpretation of George Boole. The modern interpretation says that universal categorical proposition forms do not include Existential Import, while the particulars do. This assumption fixes the problem with the traditional interpretation.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All students who get 100's on all their tests do not have to take the final.{{BR}}

Does not imply that there will be any such students by the end of the term.

@@ All pheasants are birds.{{BR}}

Does not imply the existence of pheasants.

@@ No pine trees are maples.{{BR}}

Does not imply the existence of pine trees.

@@ All satyrs are vile creatures.{{BR}}

Does not imply the existence of satyrs.

Aristotle's Interpretation

[[Description]]

@@ According to the Stanford Encyclopedia of Logic (Terence Parsons, http://plato.stanford.edu, Square of Opposition), there is quite a bit of evidence to suggest that Aristotle's interpretation was quite different from that which has been traditionally attributed to him (i.e. the Traditional Interpretation). Parsons convincingly argues that Aristotle gave existential import to the affirmatives, while the negatives lacked it.

@@ Only by this interpretation, is it possible to derive the entire Square of Opposition as theorems.

Proof Theory

Immediate Inferences

[[Description]]

@@ A deductive argument consisting of one premise and one conclusion.

Direct

[[Description]]

@@ An immediate inference in which we duduce something directly from the premise.

Contradictories

[[Description]]

@@ The proposition form pairs (A,O) and (E,I) are said to be contradictories because they necessarily have opposite truth values. If A, then not O. If O, then not A. If not A then O, etc...

[[Conditions]]: unordered

@@ Traditional Interpretation: valid{{BR}}

Modern Interpretation: invalid{{BR}}

Aristotlean Interpretation: valid

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All cats are mammals.{{BR}}

<B>âˆ´</B> It is not the case that some cats are not mammals.

@@ No birds are mammals.{{BR}}

<B>âˆ´</B> It is false that some birds are mammals.

Contraries

[[Description]]

@@ A and E form propositions are said to be contraries, this means that they cannot both be true. If A then not E. If E then not A.

[[Conditions]]: unordered

@@ In all interpretations valid if and only if the subject term really does exist.

[[Examples]]: unordered

@@ All cats are mammals.{{BR}}

<B>âˆ´</B> It is not the case that no cats are mammals.

@@ No birds are mammals.{{BR}}

<B>âˆ´</B> It is not the case that all cats are mammals.
